narrative: Coastal System Brings Widespread Snowfall December 9 - 10th. A steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM on December 9th, quickly becoming moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon, with snowfall rates reaching 0.5 - 1.0" per hour. The snow lightened up a bit after sunset, but continued to fall steadily through the evening hours. Most of the snow tapered off between 1:00 and 3:00 AM December 10th, but a few flurries lingered through sunrise. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to 30 - 32 degrees for most of the snowfall.

Temperatures warmed above freezing during the late afternoon and evening, changing any leftover precipitation to plain rain.

Snow Changes to Wintry Mix December 22nd. Intermittent periods of light snow entered the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM December 22nd with temperatures in the upper 20s. The snow began to mix with rain and freezing rain between 6:00 and 8:00 PM that evening as temperatures climbed into the mid 30s. A cold north wind brought sub-freezing temperatures back into the area by 10:00 - 11:00 PM, changing any precipitation to freezing rain and causing any wet surface to quickly freeze up. The freezing rain and drizzle tapered off by 12:00 - 2:00 AM December 23rd with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s. Note: The freezing rain and ice that occurred later on December 23rd will be covered in another report.

Christmas Day Winter Storm. A mix of light rain and snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM December 25th with temperatures in the mid 30s. Much colder air rushed into the area between 6:30 and 7:30 AM, changing precipitation to all snow with temperatures falling into the low to mid 20s. Any lingering wet or slushy areas quickly turned to ice. The snow became very heavy, with rates reaching 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands, before tapering off 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM. Northerly winds became very gusty towards the end of the event, with gusts reaching 35 - 45 mph.

Most of the steady snow tapered off by late morning, but intermittent snow showers continued through 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM. Temperatures were steady in the mid 20s throughout the event. Northerly winds became very gusty towards the end of the event, with gusts reaching 30 - 40 mph.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Blizzard-Like Conditions. A steady snow moved into the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM January 4th. The snow quickly became heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours, with rates reaching 2-3" per hour. As the snow became heavier, northwest winds began gusting to 40 - 50 mph, causing significant blowing and drifting snow. The steady snow and strong winds continued through the evening hours, before tapering off between 8:00 and 10:00 PM. Blowing and drifitng snow continued through the overnight hours, well after the falling snow ended. Temperatures were steady between 25 and 30 degrees throughout the event. . Note. : . The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Rain Mixes with Sleet and Wet Snow March 2nd. A mix of rain, snow, and sleet moved into the area between 12:00 and 2:00 AM March 2nd with temperatures in the mid 30s. Any mixture quickly changed to all rain between 5:00 and 7:00 AM that morning as temperatures rose into the upper 30s. As the precipitation exited during the afternoon and evening, the rain mixed with a bit of wet snow between 2:00 and 6:00 PM that same day. Strong northerly winds gusted to 45 - 55 mph at times during the storm.

Rain Mixes with Sleet and Wet Snow March 2nd. A mix of rain, snow, and sleet moved into the area between 1:00 and 3:00 AM March 2nd with temperatures in the mid 30s. Any mixture quickly changed to all rain between 4:00 and 7:00 AM that morning as temperatures rose into the upper 30s. As the precipitation was exiting during the evening, the rain mixed with, and changed to a period of wet snow between 8:00 PM that evening and 12:00 AM March 3rd. Strong northerly winds gusted to 45 - 55 mph at times during the storm.

Rain Mixes with Sleet and Wet Snow March 2nd. A mix of rain, snow, and sleet moved into the area between 1:00 and 3:00 AM March 2nd with temperatures in the mid 30s. Any mixture quickly changed to all rain between 4:00 and 7:00 AM that morning as temperatures rose into the upper 30s. As the precipitation was exiting during the evening, the rain mixed with, and changed to a period of wet snow between 8:00 PM that evening and 12:00 AM March 3rd. Strong northerly winds gusted to 45 - 55 mph at times during the storm.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th. A period of light to moderate snow moved through the area between 11:00 PM March 4th and 7:00 AM March 5th. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to 32 by the end of the event.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th. A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 PM March 4th. The snow continued through the evening, becoming more intermittent through the overnight. The intermittent periods of light snow and flurries came to an end between 6:00 and 8:00 AM March 5th. Temperatures were steady between 32 - 35 degrees throughout the event.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th. A few periods of light snow moved through the area between 6:00 and 10:00 PM March 4th, the snow tapered to scattered flurries during the overnight hours. Another period of steady light to moderate snow moved through the area between 2:00 and 7:00 AM March 5th. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th. After a few snow showers and flurries during the evening on March 4th, a steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 1:00 and 3:00 AM March 5th. The snow continued through 5:00 to 7:00 AM that same morning. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to 30 - 32 by the end of the event.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th. A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 9:00 and 11:00 PM March 4th. The snow continued through the overnight, before tapering off between 8:00 and 10:00 AM March 5th. The snow mixed with some rain at times, especially at the onset and towards the end. Temperatures ranged from 32 - 36 degrees throughout the event.

Rain Changes to Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th. After few rain and snow showers during the early morning hours on March 7th, a steady light to moderate rain entered the area through the afternoon. As colder air moved into the area, the rain changed to snow between 7:00 and 9:00 PM that evening. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times during the overnight, before lightening up a bit after sunrise on the 8th. Snowfall rates reached 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands. Light to occasionally moderate snow lingered during the daytime of the 8th, ending 12:00 - 3:00 PM. Temperatures settled to 31 - 34 degrees during snowfall, and winds gusted 30 - 45 mph.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th. Intermittent periods of light to moderate snow entered the area between 4:00 and 6:00 AM March 7th. Pockets of light snow continued through the morning hours, becoming very heavy at times during the afternoon and evening. Snowfall rates reached 2 - 3" per hour in the heaviest bands. The heaviest snow lightened up during the late evening hours, but a steady light to moderate snow continued through 7:00 to 10:00 AM March 8th. Temperatures were steady between 30 - 34 degrees throughout the event. A few flurries then returned late afternoon and early evening on the 8th.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th. After a few early morning snow showers and flurries, a steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM March 7th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times, with snowfall rates reaching 2 - 3" per hour during the evening. The snow lightened up a bit after midnight, but a steady light to moderate snow continued through 11:00AM to 2:00PM March 8th. Temperatures were steady between 29 - 33 degrees throughout the event. A final period of intermittent flurries returned during the early evening of the 8th.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th. After a few early morning snow showers and flurries, a steady snow entered the area between 7:00 and 9:00 AM March 7th.  The snow mixed with, and briefly changed to rain between 4:00 and 8:00 PM that evening as temperatutres rose into the mid-30s, before quickly changing back to all snow. The snow became moderate to heavy at times, with snowfall rates reaching 2 - 3" per hour overnight. By morning, the snow lightened up with periods of light to moderate snow ending between 12:00 and 3:00 PM March 8th. Temperatures were generally 30 - 33 degrees in snow with wind gusts to 25 - 35 mph.

Rain Ends as Wet Snow March 8th. Periods of heavy rain ended with some periods of wet snow between 4:00 and 10:00 AM March 8th. Some places ended mixed with rain again. Temperatures began in the upper 30s when the snow began, but fell to 32 - 34 by the end of the event.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th. Initial light rain showers began as early as 12AM, before becoming a steady snow by 2 - 4AM on the 13th as temperatures settled from the upper 30s to near 32 degrees. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 7AM - 7PM when snowfall rates of 1 - 2" per hour occurred. The main area of snow ended by 11PM, though intermittent light snow lingered until 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during snowfall were mainly 30 - 32 degrees, and winds gusted 30 - 50 mph, resulting in blizzard conditions.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th. Intermittent flurries began as early as 11PM on the 12th, before becoming a steadier snow 2 - 4AM on the 13th. This became moderate to heavy at times between 8AM - 4PM. Snow turned lighter into the evening, ending 9 - 11PM. Temperatures during the event initially began 33 - 35 degrees, then settled to 30 - 33 degrees during the majority of snowfall, with wind gusts of 20 - 30 mph.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th. Intermittent flurries began as early as 10PM on the 12th, before becoming a steadier snow 1 - 3AM on the 13th. Snow quickly turned moderate to heavy through the majority of the event, particularly between 10AM - 5PM where 1 - 3" per hour snowfall rates occurred. By the evening, snow turned lighter, and completely ended 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during snowfall settled to 28 - 32 degrees, with wind gusts of 25 - 35 mph at times.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th. Initial light rain / snow showers began as early as 12AM, before becoming a steady snow by 2 - 4AM on the 13th. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 7AM - 7PM when snowfall rates of 2 - 4" per hour occurred. The main area of snow ended by 11PM, though intermittent light snow lingered until 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during the event began 33 - 37 degrees, then settled to 29 - 32 degrees throughout. Winds gusted to 25 - 35 mph.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th. Initial light rain showers began as early as 12AM, before becoming a steady snow by 3 - 4AM on the 13th as temperatures settled from the upper 30s to near 32 degrees. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 7AM - 7PM when snowfall rates of 1 - 2" per hour occurred. The main area of snow ended by 10PM, though intermittent light snow lingered until 12AM on the 14th. Temperatures during snowfall were 32 - 34 degrees, and winds gusted 50 - 80 mph, resulting in blizzard conditions.
Post-Coastal Storm Snow Showers March 14 - 15th. A period of light snow moved through the area between 10:00 PM March 14th and 4:00 AM March 15th Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees.
Post-Coastal Storm Snow Shower March 14th. A brief snow shower moved through the area between 4:00 and 6:00 PM March 14th Temperatures ranged from 32 - 36 degrees.

Post-Coastal Storm Snow Showers March 14th. Snow showers entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM March 14th.These snow showers and flurries continued intermittently through the afternoon and evening, before tapering off between 10:00 PM that evening and 1:00 AM March 15th. Temperatures began in the upper 20s, but rose to 32 - 34 degrees during the afternoon. The temperatures then fell back into the 20s overnight.
Post-Coastal Storm Snow Showers March 14 - 15th. A period of light snow moved through the area between 10:00 PM March 14th and 4:00 AM March 15th Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees.
Post-Coastal Storm Snow Showers March 14 - 15th. A period of light snow moved through the area between 11:00 PM March 14th and 4:00 AM March 15th Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees.

Coastal System Brings Period of Snow March 22nd. Light rain and snow entered the area between 11:00 PM March 21st and 1:00 AM March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 35 - 39 degrees. The precipitation quickly changed to all snow, becoming moderate at times after sunrise. During the snow, temperatures fell to 32 - 34 degrees. The snow came to an end between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM that same day.
Rain and Snow Showers March 22nd. A few light rain and snow showers moved through the area between 1:00 and 8:00 AM March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 33 - 36 degrees.

Coastal System Brings Period of Snow March 22nd. Light snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 32 - 34 degrees. The snow became moderate at times, before ending between 9:00 and 11:00 AM that morning. During the snow, temperatures fell to 30 - 32 degrees.

Coastal System Brings Period of Snow March 22nd. Light snow entered the area between 3:00 and 5:00 AM March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 32 - 34 degrees. The snow became moderate at times, before ending between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM that day. During the snow, temperatures fell to 30 - 32 degrees.

Coastal System Brings Mix of Rain and Wet Snow March 21-22nd. A mix of rain and wet snow entered the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM March 21st with temperatures in the mid to upper 30s. The mixture continued to fall through the overnight, before changing to mostly snow during the morning hours on March 22nd. When the precipitation changed to all snow, temperatures fell to 33 - 35 degrees. The snow came to an end between 1:00 and 3:00 PM March 22nd.

Snow Showers March 25th. Scattered snow showers (mixed with rain at times) moved through the area between 11:00 PM March 24th and 6:00 AM March 25th. Some additional, non-accumulating snow showers and flurries continued into the afternoon. Temperatures ranged from 33 - 36 degrees.
Brief Snow Shower/Flurry March 25th. A few light snow showers and flurries moved through the area between 5:00 and 8:00 AM March 25th. Temperatures were in the upper 20s.
Snow Showers March 25th. Scattered snow showers moved through the area between 2:00 and 8:00 AM March 25th. Temperatures ranged from 27 - 32 degrees.

Snow Showers March 25th. Scattered snow showers (mixed with rain at times) moved through the area between 11:00 PM and 6:00 AM March 25th. Some additional, non-accumulating snow showers and flurries continued into the afternoon. Temperatures ranged from 33 - 36 degrees.

Rain and Snow Showers March 25th. Scattered rain and snow showers moved through the area between 1:00 and 7:00 AM March 25th. Some additional, non-accumulating snow showers continued into the afternoon. Temperatures ranged from 33 - 37 degrees.

Fast Moving Storm Brings April Snow. A steady snow entered the area between 7:00 and 9:00 AM April 2nd. The snow became moderate to heavy at times during the mid-morning, before ending between 12:00 and 2:00 PM that same day. Temperatures ranged from 31 - 34 degrees. Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Fast Moving Storm Brings April Snow. A steady snow entered the area between 5:00 and 7:00 AM April 2nd. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 31 degrees. Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Temperatures ranged from 28 - 31 degrees. Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Yet Another Early April Snow Event. Snow entered the area between 12:00 and 2:00 PM April 6th. The snow was briefly moderate to heavy at times, before tapering off between 3:00 and 5:00 PM. The snow mixed with rain towards the end of the event. Temperatures began in the upper 30s, but fell to 32 - 35 during the snow. Due to warm ground temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on non-paved surfaces.

Yet Another Early April Snow Event. Snow entered the area between 11:00 AM and 1:00 PM April 6th. The snow was briefly moderate to heavy at times, before tapering off between 2:00 and 4:00 PM. Temperatures began in the upper 30s, but fell to 32 - 35 during the snow. Due to warm ground temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on non-paved surfaces.

Snow Changes to Rain April 6th. A brief period of snow moved through the area between 12:00 and 5:00 PM April 6th, before changing to all rain. Temperatures were in the mid 30s during the snow. Due to warm ground temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on non-paved surfaces.

Periods of Wintry Mix Change to Rain April 15-16th. A light mix of snow and sleet moved into the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM April 15th with temperatures ranging from 32 - 35 degrees. A wintry mix of sleet, snow, and rain continued into the evening, before changing to plain rain between 10:00 PM that evening and 1:00 AM April 16th. As the precipitation changed to rain, temperatures rose into the upper 30s.

Periods of Wintry Mix Change to Rain April 15-16th. A light mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain entered the area between 5:00 and 7:00 PM April 15th with temperatures in the upper 20s. The periods of sleet and freezing rain continued through the overnight, before the precipitation changed to plain rain between 8:00 and 10:00 AM April 16th. After the precipitation changed to plain rain, temperatures rose into the upper 30s.

Periods of Wintry Mix Change to Rain April 15-16th. After a few light snow and sleet showers moved through during the late morning, a steady mixture of snow, sleet, and freezing rain developed between 4:00 and 6:00 PM April 15th with temperatures ranging from 29 - 32 degrees. The periods of wintry precipitation continued through the overnight, before the precipitation changed to plain rain between 8:00 and 10:00 AM April 16th. After the precipitation changed to plain rain, temperatures rose into the upper 30s.

Periods of Wintry Mix Change to Rain April 15-16th. After a few light snow and sleet showers moved through during the late morning, a steady mixture of snow, sleet, and freezing rain developed between 8:00 and 10:00 PM April 15th with temperatures ranging from 31 - 33 degrees. The periods of wintry precipitation continued through the overnight, before the precipitation changed to plain rain between 4:00 and 6:00 AM April 16th as temperatures rose above freezing. After the precipitation changed to plain rain, temperatures rose into the upper 30s.

Brief Period of Rain, Sleet, and Wet Snow April 19th. A brief period of rain, sleet, and wet snow moved through the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM April 19th with temperatures ranging from 34 - 37 degrees.

Another Late Seasonal Snowfall Impacts the Area. A period of light to moderate snow (mixed with sleet and rain at times) moved through the area between 6:00 and 11:00 AM April 19th with temperatures ranging from 32 - 34 degrees.

Another Late Seasonal Snowfall Impacts the Area. A period of light to moderate snow (mixed with sleet and rain at times) moved through the area between 6:00 and 11:00 AM April 19th with temperatures ranging from 32 - 34 degrees.
Another Late Seasonal Snowfall Impacts the Area. Light rain changed to a period of wet snow and sleet between 8:00 and 11:00 AM April 19th. Temperatures were in the mid 30s.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th. A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 8 - 10 AM as temperatures cooled from the mid-30s to between 30 - 34 degrees. As snow quickly became steadier toward mid-day, it also became moderate in intensity at times, especially between 11 AM - 4 PM. Snow then remained light and steady into the evening, eventually diminishing by 10 PM - 12 AM into the 10th with a few flurries lingering after. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th. A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 9 - 11 AM as temperatures cooled from the mid-30s to between 30 - 34 degrees. As snow quickly became steadier toward mid-day, it also became moderate in intensity at times, especially between 10 AM - 3 PM. On and off light snow then continued into the evening, eventually diminishing by 11 PM - 1 AM with lingering flurries into the pre-dawn hours on the 10th. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th. A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 8 - 10 AM. As snow quickly became steadier toward the late morning, it also became moderate (and briefly heavy) in intensity at times, especially between 10 AM - 4 PM. Snow then remained light and steady into the evening, eventually diminishing by 10 PM - 12 AM with just a few flurries lingering into the 10th. Temperatures were generally between 27 - 32 degrees during the event.

Scattered flurries and snow showers briefly occurred between 4 - 8 AM on December 11th. Temperatures were between 31 - 34 degrees during the event before rising into the upper 30s to 40 degrees by mid-day.

Scattered flurries and snow showers briefly occurred between 4 - 8 AM on December 11th. Temperatures were between 31 - 34 degrees during the event before rising into the upper 30s to 40 degrees by mid-day.

Light clipper system on December 14th. A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 3 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent with just flurries at times, especially toward and around dawn. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 8 - 11 AM. Temperatures were generally between 23 - 28 degrees during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Light clipper system on December 14th. A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 3 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent with just flurries at times, especially toward and around dawn. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 8 - 11 AM. Temperatures were generally between 23 - 28 degrees during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Light clipper system on December 14th. A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 2 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow then continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent at times with just flurries. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 7 - 9 AM. Temperatures were generally in the low-to-mid 20s during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th. Snow quickly developed between 1 - 3 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. The snow came to an end west to east 7 - 9 PM. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s, but settled into the mid 20s as snow became steady.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th. Snow quickly developed between 1 - 3 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. The snow came to an end west to east 8 - 11 PM. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s to near 30, but settled to 24 - 28 degrees during the steady snow.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th. Snow quickly developed between 2 - 4 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with some pockets of moderate snow. Snow did not last long, and tapered off between 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures were mainly in the low 20s during snowfall.

Clipper system on December 30th. Light snow flurries associated with a clipper developed between 8 - 10 AM on the 30th. Snow became steadiest through mid-day before quickly tapering off by 2 - 4 PM. Temperatures held between 19 - 23 during snowfall. Note: Areas that saw returning showers or flurries during the evening of 12/30 will be addressed in a separate storm summary.

Clipper system on December 30th. As a clipper moved on the morning of the 30th, light snow flurries developed between 8 - 10 AM. These were spotty with some areas seeing lulls before steadier snow developed toward mid-day, becoming moderate to even heavy at times between 11 AM - 3 PM. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held between 18 - 21 degrees during snowfall. Note: Areas that saw returning showers or flurries during the evening of 12/30 will be addressed in a separate storm summary.

Clipper system on December 30th. As a clipper moved in on the morning of the 30th, light snow developed between 7 - 9 AM. This became steady through mid-day, especially between 10 AM - 1 PM with brief moderate bursts of snow. Snow then tapered off to flurries by 2 - 4 PM. Temperatures were initially in the low-to-mid 20s before rising to near 20 degrees during snowfall.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Region. Initial sporadic snow developed across the area as early as 12 - 2 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the upper 20s to around 30 degrees. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 4 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the mid-20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 1 - 2 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 3 - 6 PM. In addition to the heavy snow were strong winds which were sustained at 15 - 30 mph, but gusted 45 - 55 mph at times. . The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Long Island. Initial sporadic snow developed across Long Island as early as 12 - 2 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the upper 20s to around 30 degrees. A few spots across the Twin Forks briefly mixed with rain near 32 degrees during this time before cooling. Otherwise, after a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 5 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the middle 20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 2 - 3 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 4 - 7 PM, though pockets of snow persisted in spots until nearly Midnight, especially across the Twin Forks. In addition to the heavy snow, winds were very strong, sustained at 15 - 30 mph and gusted up to 45 - 60 mph at times resulting in blizzard-like conditions. . The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow. Initial sporadic snow flurries developed as early as 2 - 4 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the mid-20s. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 5 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the low 20s to near 20 degrees where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 1 - 2 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 4 - 7 PM with a lingering flurry in the evening. In addition to the heavy snow were strong winds which were sustained at 15 - 30 mph, but gusted 45 - 55 mph at times. . The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Wintry mix on January 8th. A weak system moved into the area between 3 - 6 PM on the 8th, which brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain. Steadier precipitation changed to all snow for a time, especially after sunset. Temperatures were between 27 - 31 degrees during the event.

Wintry mix on January 8th. Initial rain overspread Long Island by 3 - 5 PM on the 8th with temperatures between 34 - 36 degrees. Periodic mixes of sleet, snow, and freezing rain then followed into the early evening as temperatures cooled to between 30 - 32 degrees. Most areas stopped precipitating by 8 PM but wintry mixes continued along the South Shore and the South Fork until 10-11 PM before ending.

Wintry mix to snow on January 8th. A light mix of sleet and freezing rain began across the region between 12 - 2 PM on the 8th. This mix quickly changed to mainly snow within an hour of any precipitation that started. Light snow then continued before tapering off by 3 - 6 PM. Temperatures were in the mid-20s during the event.

Storm brought rain to snow on January 17th. A steady rain moved into the area overnight on the 17th with temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s. This eventually mixed and changed to snow by 7 - 9 AM as temperatures settled between 32 - 36 degrees. Snow then remained light to moderate, eventually tapering off to flurries 1 - 4 PM.

Storm brought rain to snow on January 17th. Rain fell during the pre-dawn hours on the 17th with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. Rain then mixed and changed to a light to briefly moderate wet snow by 9 AM - 12 PM as temperatures settled between 33 - 36 degrees. Any snow or rain/snow mix then ended by 2 - 5 PM.

Accumulating snow and wintry mix on January 16-17. Pockets of flurries and light to moderate snow developed between 5 - 9 AM on the 16th. This initial snow was brief, with temperatures in the low-to-mid 20s before being followed by a break in precipitation outside of a few spotty flurries or sprinkles during the day. A second batch of precipitation then fell as rain near midnight on the 17th but since temperatures warmed between 30 - 34 degrees, freezing rain and brief sleet developed in spots. Any rain or mix then changed over to snow by 6 - 8 AM, remaining light to moderate in intensity before tapering off to flurries by 1 - 3 PM.

Coastal system on January 29 - 30. Pockets of light snow and flurries began as early as the late evening on January 29th, before becoming steady during the pre-dawn on the 30th. Snow then remained light to moderate through the morning, eventually tapering off to flurries by 6 - 9 AM. Temperatures were initially 33 - 36 degrees before settling between 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall. Due to prior mild temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable, and generally less than those of colder and grassy surfaces.

Coastal storm on January 29 - 30. Pockets of light snow and flurries developed as early as 7 - 10 PM on January 29th, quickly becoming steady by and after midnight on the 30th. Snow became moderate to heavy during the pre-dawn hours, with some of the heaviest falling at rates of 1-2" per hour. This then trended back to a light to moderate snow toward daybreak, eventually tapering down to flurries by 11 AM - 1 PM (the Twin Forks continued to see flurries through 3 - 4 PM). Temperatures were initially in the low-to-mid 30s before settling between 26 - 31 degrees during snowfall. Note: Returning snow showers during the evening of January 30th will be covered in a separate report.

Coastal system grazed the area on January 30th. As a coastal system moved mainly to the east, the western edge of precipitation grazed the region on January 30th. Pockets of light snow and flurries developed around 12 AM with temperatures in the mid-30s, continuing through the pre-dawn with temperatures cooling between 28 - 32 degrees. While initially light, snow became moderate and steady through dawn before tapering off to flurries by 7 - 10 AM. Some sunshine returned after, warming temperatures between 32 - 36 degrees. Spotty flurries and brief showers continued otherwise, especially in the early afternoon and early evening. Snow eventually tapered off by 9 PM to just lingering flurries with temperatures falling back into the teens and 20s.

Snow to wintry mix and rain on February 7th. A light to moderate snow overspread the area between 7 - 9 AM on February 7th, quickly mixing with sleet as temperatures were initially between 30 - 32 degrees. Snow then changed to mainly freezing rain by 11 AM - 12 PM as temperatures held near 32 degrees. Temperatures then slowly warmed above freezing by 1 - 3 PM, ending any icing. Marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation led to accumulations that were denser than normal.

Morning wintry mix on February 7th. Snow mixed with some sleet overspread Long Island between 8 - 10 AM on February 7th. With temperatures between 30 - 35 degrees, pockets of freezing rain quickly developed through the morning outside of the East End which changed to all rain due to temperatures in the mid-30s. Any wintry mix otherwise changed to rain by 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures warmed well into the 30s and even 40s during the afternoon. Even though accumulations were not that high, they were more dense than normal due to marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation.

Snow to wintry mix and rain on February 7th. Light to moderate snow overspread the area between 7 - 9 AM on February 7th. Snow was steady with temperatures between 25 - 30 degrees. Sleet then mixed in by 10 - 11 AM, with freezing rain also quickly developing toward noon. As temperatures held near 32 degrees, mixes of sleet and freezing rain then continued until 3 - 5 PM before warming above freezing in the mid-to-upper 30s, ending any icing. Marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation led to accumulations that were denser than normal.

Periods of steady, heavy snow on February 17 - 18. Snow overspread the area between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th, quickly becoming steady during the evening. Moderate to heavy snow fell between 7 and 10 PM, with the steadiest falling at rates of up to 1-2" per hour. This then tapered to off to snow showers and flurries toward midnight (with a brief changeover to light rain in spots). All precipitiation ended by 2 AM on the 18th. Temperatures held steady between 30 - 34 degrees during the event.

Mixes of snow and rain on February 17 - 18. With temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s, sprinkles and flurries began falling between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th. Steady precipitation then overspread Long Island by 7 - 8 PM, with combinations of snow and rain falling through midnight as temperatures cooled between 32 - 35 degrees. Any lingering mixed showers and flurries ended by 2 - 5 AM on the 18th.

Periods of steady, heavy snow fell on February 17 - 18. Snow developed between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th, quickly becoming steady and heavy into the evening. The heaviest fell at rates of 1-3" per hour, especially between 6 and 11 PM. Snow then became intermittent by midnight, with any lingering snow showers and flurries ending between 12 - 3 AM on the 18th. Temperatures held steady between 29 - 32 degrees during snowfall.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind on March 2nd. A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. A good portion of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1st). Starting 7 - 9 AM on March 2nd, rain mixed with and at points changed to combinations of snow and sleet. This mixture of precipitation continued through the afternoon, until the steady precipitation tapered down to flurries and sprinkles between 5 and 8 PM. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 33 and 38 degrees. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40 - 50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Occasional Snow and Sleet on March 2nd. A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to Long Island on March 2nd. While the majority of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1st), precipitation mixed with and even changed to combinations of snow and sleet at times during the day. The mixing with snow and sleet began as early as 7 - 10 AM, and persisted at times through the day. Most of the steady precipitation tapered down between 6 and 9 PM, though some pockets of light rain and wet snow persisted until 12 - 2 AM on March 3rd. In addition to the wintry mix of precipitation, winds were quite strong, gusting frequently up to 40 - 50 mph, with some spots exceeding 65 mph at times. At times of mixed precipitation, temperatures were mostly 33 - 37 degrees.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind on March 2nd. A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. The first portion of precipitation (which began late on March 1st) was in the form of plain rain. Starting as early as 12 -3 AM however, rain mixed with and changed to snow, which came down moderate to heavily at points as temperatures settled between 32 - 36 degrees. Some of this snow came down at rates of 1-3" per hour through the rest of the morning and afternoon. Precipitation finally came to an end between 7 and 10 PM, with a few additional flurries lingering overnight. Marginal temperatures led to variable snow accumulations between lower and higher elevations. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong, frequently gusting between 35 and 50 miles per hour which resulted in blowing and drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Light snow on March 4th and 5th. Flurries and snow showers began as early as 7 PM on the evening of the 4th, with more widespread light snow developing mainly between 10 PM - 3 AM into the 5th. While most of the snow had finished by then, additional flurries and brief pockets of light snow did continue to fall at times across the East End until 8 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 31 - 35 degrees under the steadiest snow.

Light snow on March 4th and 5th. Flurries and snow showers began as early as 7 PM on the evening of the 4th, with more widespread light snow developing mainly between 10 PM - 3 AM into the 5th. While most of the snow had finished by then, additional flurries and brief pockets of light snow did continue to fall at times across the East End until 8 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 31 - 35 degrees under the steadiest snow.

Snow showers and flurries on March 4th and 5th. Snow showers and flurries began as early as 5 - 7 PM on March 4th, continuing intermittently overnight before dissipating by 2 - 4 AM on March 5th. Temperatures were generally between 33 - 38 degrees but cooled to 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall.

Long duration event featuring a wintry mix on March 7th. A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting during the evening. The first batch of precipitation was a mix of light snow and rain that began shortly after 12 AM on the 7th. This mixture then continued before abruptly transitioning to moderate to heavy snow between 12 and 3 PM as the coastal system developed. The heaviest snow was accompanied by thunder and snowfall rates up to 1" per hour at times. Snow then continued into the evening, mixing with rain again before ending between 8 - 10 PM with just a few lingering flurries. Temperatures were generally between 33 and 37 degrees throughout the event. . Additionally. , winds gusted between 35 - 45 mph during the heaviest precipitation which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Long duration event featuring a wintry mix on March 7th and 8th. A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting on the 8th. The first batch of precipitation was a mix of light snow and rain across the region between 1 and 7 AM on the 7th, followed by a few lulls in precipitation afterwards. A steadier mix of rain, snow, and sleet then began after 9 AM with the coastal system. This mix switched to a heavy snow as early as 12 PM, although areas toward the East End did not change over until 3 - 6 PM. The heaviest snow was accompanied by thunder and snowfall rates up to 1-2" per hour. Combinations of rain and snow continued into the evening before eventually tapering off between 1 and 4 AM on March 8th. Temperatures were generally between 32 and 37 degrees throughout the event. Additionally. , winds gusted between 35 - 45 mph during the heaviest precipitation which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Long duration event featuring heavy snow on March 7th and 8th. A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting during the evening. The first batch of precipitation were pockets of light to moderate snow that developed shortly after midnight on the 7th (of which began as flurries late on the 6th mixed with some rain) before lulling at times toward dawn. Steadier precipitation then developed after daybreak with the coastal system, resulting in moderate to heavy snow falling by 10 AM - 12 PM. Snow fell at rates of up to 2-4" per hour under the heaviest of snow through the afternoon. This snow then quickly tapered off between 6 and 9 PM, although additional snow showers and flurries lingered until 3 AM on March 8th. Temperatures were mainly between 30 - 34 degrees during the event. . Additionally. , winds gusted up to 30 - 35 mph during the heaviest precipitation, which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 13th. Light rain began late in the evening on March 12th, mixing and changing to snow after 12 AM on the 13th. Periods of light to moderate snow then followed into the early morning hours, becoming heavy for a time between 6 and 9 AM. Snow then became lighter after 11 AM, mixing with rain at times before completely ending by 1 - 3 PM. Temperatures were mainly between 33 and 37 degrees throughout the storm.

Nor'easter brings heavy snowfall on March 13th. After rain brief fell late in the evening on March 12th, precipitation changed to snow around midnight on the 13th. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the pre-dawn as heavy bands developed across Long Island. These bands produced snowfall rates up to 1-3" per hour. In addition, winds also gusted up to and over 35 - 40 mph, which resulted in blowing and drifting snow. The heavy snow gradually trended lighter after 10 AM, ending for most between 12 - 3 PM. However, heavy bands of snow continued to linger across the Twin Forks until 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures were between 31 and 36 degrees throughout the storm.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 13th. Pockets of light snow began between 10 PM and Midnight on March 12th (which briefly mixed with rain in spots) before giving way to steadier snowfall after 12 AM on the 13th. Snow became moderate to even heavy at times toward dawn, with snowfall rates up to 1" per hour as heavier bands developed through daybreak. Snow then trended lighter after 8 AM, giving way to snow showers and flurries that lingered until 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures were mainly between 32 and 37 degrees during snowfall.

Evening snow showers and flurries on March 14th. Flurries began as early as 4 - 5 PM, followed by scattered snow showers mainly between 6 PM and 12 AM on March 14th. While most precipitation was light, a few showers did become heavy and steady at times. Snow quickly tapered down to flurries by midnight, eventually diminishing shortly afterwards. Temperatures were initially in the upper 30s to near 40 degrees before cooling between 33 and 37 degrees during snowfall.

Evening snow showers and flurries on March 14th. Scattered snow showers and flurries developed across Long Island between 5 and 11 PM on March 14th. These became briefly heavy and steady times before tapering down to flurries through midnight on the 15th. Temperatures were between 32 and 37 degrees during the event.

Afternoon and evening snow showers on March 14th. Snow showers and flurries developed as early as 2 - 3 PM with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. These continued into the evening as temperatures cooled between 30 and 34 degrees. A few showers became briefly steady and heavy at times. Snow otherwise diminished to flurries by 9 PM - 12 AM.

Brief wintry mix on March 20th. Pockets of sleet, mixed with some rain and brief snow, occurred between 4 and 9 PM on March 20th. Temperatures were between 36 and 40 degrees, with most accumulation found on colder/grassy surfaces. Temperatures continued to hold in the mid-to-upper 30s after sleet ended.

Brief wintry mix on March 20th. Pockets of sleet, mixed with some rain and brief snow, occurred between 4 and 9 PM on March 20th. Temperatures were between 36 and 40 degrees, with most accumulation found on colder/grassy surfaces. Temperatures continued to hold in the mid-to-upper 30s after sleet ended.

Major late season nor'easter on March 21st and 22nd. Flurries and spotty sleet began between 1 and 4 AM on March 21st, becoming steadier after 7 - 8 AM as a nor'easter moved in. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy and continued throughout the rest of the day, with sleet mixing in at times until the mid-afternoon. The heaviest of snow fell at rates up to 1-3" per hour. While snow lightened up after midnight on March 22nd, it did not completely end until 5 - 8 AM. Temperatures were initially in the mid-30s before settling between 30 and 34 degrees for the duration of the storm.

Significant late season nor'easter on March 21st and 22nd. Intermittent mixes of flurries, sleet, and rain began during the pre-dawn hours on March 21st, with temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s. Precipitation quickly became steady after 8 - 9 AM as temperatures cooled to 30 and 34 degrees and held throughout the storm. Snow continued to mix with sleet at times until the mid-late afternoon, becoming moderate to heavy. Very heavy bands of snow developed across Long Island by the evening, of which fell up to rates of 2-5" per hour. Snow then trended lighter after midnight on the 22nd, although pockets of moderate snow continued to fall at times before completely ending by 7 - 10 AM.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 21st and 22nd. Flurries and brief sleet pellets began falling as early as the pre-dawn hours on March 21st with temperatures in the mid-30s. By 7 - 9 AM, steadier snow (some of which was still intermittent in spots during the morning) arrived with a nor'easter as temperatures cooled to 30 and 32 degrees and remained there through the rest of the storm. Snow was moderate to heavy at times by the afternoon and early evening. Snow eventually ended between 4 and 6 AM on March 22nd followed by a few lingering flurries.

Fast last season system on April 2nd. Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 3 and 5 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 9 and 11 AM, with flurries lingering until noon. Temperatures were between 32 and 36 degrees during snowfall before warming into low 40s in the afternoon.

Fast last season system on April 2nd. Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 4:30 and 6 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 10 AM and 12 PM. Temperatures were between 30 and 34 degrees during snowfall before warming into low 40s in the afternoon.

Fast last season system on April 2nd. Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 2 and 4 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 10 AM and 12 PM. Temperatures were between 27 and 33 degrees during snowfall before warming into the upper 30s and low 40s in the afternoon.

First Winter Storm of the Season Occurred December 9th-10th. Light to moderate snow began between 8 AM - 10 AM on the 9th with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. Once snow became steadier Midday, temperatures quickly plummeted below freezing (29 - 32 degrees), with even some bursts of brief, heavy snow. Going into the evening, snowfall was light but persistent before tapering off as flurries from 1 - 4 AM on the 10th. Temperatures by the end of the event settled into the upper-20s.

First coastal storm of the season brought snow from December 9th-10th. Light to moderate snow began between 7 - 10 AM on the 9th with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. By Midday, snow was falling steadily, resulting in temperatures to dip to 29 - 32 degrees and stay there for the rest of the event. Snow began to lighten up considerably towards Midnight, ending as flurries between 11 PM - 2 AM.

Some flurries and even a little wintry mix on the front and backside of a disturbance. Intermittent flurries worked in between 12 - 2 AM on the 12th with temperatures around 32 degrees. Not long after daybreak, a steady rain moved in, with temperatures rising to 36 - 41 degrees. A bit of snow and sleet mixed in with the rain on the backside of the system before ending between 2 - 5 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event were in the mid-to-upper 30s.

A bit of wintry mix at the start/end of a mainly rain event from December 12th-13th. Light rain (mixed with some snow and sleet at the onset in elevations above 600 feet) began between 6 - 8 AM on the 12th with temperatures of 35 - 39 degrees. Rain continued into the daytime as temperatures soared to a high in the low-40s. At night, however, colder air began to funnel in behind the system, resulting in a changeover to light snow, sleet and flurries from 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures fell near to just below freezing not long after the changeover. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 1 - 3 AM on the 13th. Temperature settled to 19 - 24 degrees by the end of the event.

Light snow overspread the region between 1 - 3 AM on the 14th. The steadiest snow exited from 8 - 10 AM, with any lingering flurries tapering off by Noontime. Temperatures during the snowfall event held 21 - 26 degrees.

Light snow developed between 11 PM on the 13th and 1 AM on the 14th. While the steadiest snow ended from 7 - 9 AM, a few lingering flurries lasted through Noontime. Temperatures held 21 - 26 degrees throughout the event.

Intermittent flurries & a brief band of very light snow occurred on December 16th. Intermittent flurries began between Noon - 3 PM on December 16th with temperatures around 32 degrees. However, a slightly better band of flurries & light snow pushed through between 4 - 7 PM, with the last of any flakes dissipating by 8 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 29 - 32 degrees.

A brief period of light snow impacted the evening commute on December 15th. Light snow began between 4 - 6 PM on the 15th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures held 21 - 25 degrees throughout the event.

Quick-hitting coastal system brought some snow to the region on December 15th. Light snow began between 1 - 4 PM on the 15th with temperatures of 26 - 29 degrees. Snow was briefly moderate near the New York border during the late afternoon to early evening hours. The last of the flakes fell between 9 - 11 PM with temperatures settling to 21 - 25 degrees.

Low pressure brings a wintry mix, then long-duration icing event December 22-23.    . Intermittent light snow & sleet entered the area between 11 AM and 2 PM on the 22nd with temperatures of 25 - 30 degrees. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet and freezing rain during the evening as temperatures rose slightly to 27 - 32 degrees. Although there was a bit of a lull overnight, there were some pockets of freezing fog and freezing drizzle. Freezing rain returned to the area between 3 and 6 AM on the 23rd. The freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5 to 8 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 32 - 37 by the end of the event. The long duration of freezing rain caused repeated periods of icing.

Low pressure brings a wintry mix, then long-duration icing event December 22-23.    . Intermittent  flurries & sleet pellets entered the area between 11 AM and 2 PM on the 22nd with temperatures of 33 - 38 degrees. The flurries and sleet pellets changed over to freezing rain during the evening as temperatures dipped to 29 - 32 degrees. Although there was a bit of a lull overnight, there were some pockets of freezing fog and freezing drizzle. Freezing rain returned to the area between 2 and 5 AM on the 23rd. The freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5 to 8 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 33 - 38 by the end of the event. The long duration of freezing rain caused repeated periods of icing.

A winter storm and subsequent snow showers occurred on Christmas Day. Light snow entered the area between 10 PM and Midnight on the 24th. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet and freezing drizzle before steadier snow developed from 2 - 4 AM on the 25th. The snow fell heavy at times towards and after daybreak. Snowfall rates reach 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands. Most of the steady snow tapered off from 9 - 11a. Temperatures held steady between 27 - 32 degrees. Intermittent snow showers returned Midday with temperatures of 32 - 37 degrees. The last of the flakes dissipated 7 - 9 PM as temperatures dipped back to 29 - 32 degrees. Winds became very gusty during the daylight hours of the 25th, with gusts reaching 30 - 40 mph.

Snow, sleet, and rain mix from December 24-25. Scattered snow, sleet, rain and even some pockets of freezing rain developed between 8 - 11 PM on the 24th with temperatures of 30 - 35 degrees. Showers continued into the early morning hours of the 25th until steadier precipitation of snow and sleet moved in between 5 - 9 AM. Behind the main system, just a few lingering mixed sprinkle/flurries and rain/snow showers occurred before ending completely by Noon. Temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds also gusted up to 30 - 40 mph through the morning.

Clipper system brought some snow to the region on December 30th. Light snow began between 8 - 10 AM on the 30th. During the early afternoon, snow became briefly moderate in intensity in southern Hartford county. The last of the flakes dissipated from 4 - 6 PM. Temperatures generally held 13 - 18 degrees throughout the event, however in the steadiest afternoon snow, did dip as low as 8 - 13 degrees.

A clipper system brought light to even moderate snow to the area on the 30th. Light snow began between 7 - 9 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 14 - 17 degrees. The snow fell moderate in intensity closer to the New York border during the afternoon before lightening up before sunset. The last of the flakes dissipated from 4 - 6 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose slightly to 19 - 22 degrees.

A potent winter storm impacted the state from January 4th-5th. Intermittent light snow began between 1 - 3 AM on the 4th with temperatures of 16 - 19 degrees. A steadier light snow worked in thereafter, becoming moderate to heavy just after sunrise. Winds began to kick up with these heavier bands, as well, with gusts of 25 - 35 mph, resulting in blowing & drifting. Visibilities dipped to a quarter mile or slightly less at times. Snowfall rates of 1-3"/hr existed throughout much of the daytime. Temperatures rose to an afternoon high of 25 - 28 degrees. The heavier bands exited around sunset, resulting in a light and increasingly intermittent snow to continue as winds gusted to 30 - 40 mph. Light snow ended completely from 10 PM - 1 AM going into the 5th. Temperatures settled to 18 - 22 degrees. Winds continued to stay gusty into the overnight, resulting in blowing and drifting even into the daytime of the 5th. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

A powerful coastal system impacted the state on . January. 4th. Periods of light snow began between 2 - 4 AM on the 4th with temperatures of 23 - 28 degrees. The snow became moderate to heavy around to just after sunrise with temperatures dipping to a low of 19 - 24 degrees. Winds began to kick up with these heavier bands, as well, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph, resulting in blowing & drifting. Near-blizzard conditions were witnessed as visibilities dipped to a quarter mile or less for much of the daytime with snowfall rates of 1-3"/hr. Especially out near New Haven, lightning and thunder could be seen from over the waters. The heavier bands exited around sunset, resulting in a light and increasingly intermittent snow to continue as winds gusted to 40 - 50 mph. Any lingering flurries dissipated from 7 - 10 PM. Temperatures rose slightly back to 23 - 28 degrees. Winds continued to stay gusty into the overnight, resulting in blowing and drifting even into the daytime of the 5th. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

A wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain occurred on January 8th. Light freezing rain and sleet within the river valley with more snow and sleet in the elevations developed between 2 and 4 PM on the 8th. All areas quickly changed over to light snow from 3 - 5 PM. The last of the flakes dissipated from 6 - 8 PM. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow occurred on January 8th. A mix of light freezing rain, sleet, and snow began between 2 and 4 PM on the 8th. The wintry mix quickly changed over to all snow before the last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 28 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

A complex wintry system brought snow to the area from January 16th-17th. A few flurries and intermittent light snow began to work in as early as 9 - 11 AM on the 16th with temperatures of 23 - 26 degrees. However, the steadier snow took until 11 PM - 2 AM going into the 17th with temperatures of 29 - 32 degrees. The snow continued into the daytime on the 17th before exiting from 3 - 5 PM. However, a few flurries lingered as late as 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event hovered around 32 degrees.

January 17th winter storm brought rain and snow. A light to moderate rain arrived between 1 - 3 AM on the 17th with temperatures in the mid-30s. A gradual changeover to snow occurred from west to east from 10 AM - 1 PM. The last of the flakes dissipated from 3 - 5 PM. Temperatures hovered around 32 degrees by the end of the event.

A storm system clipped the north-central portion of the state from January 29th-30th. Light to occasionally steady snow began between 11 PM on the 29th to 2 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 27 - 32 degrees. The light snow from the main system tapered off completely from 9 - 11 AM as temperature settled into the mid-to-upper 20s. While most areas were dry for the rest of the calendar day, those within the higher hills saw a few flurries or very light snow showers between 9 - 11 PM with much colder temperatures in the upper-teens to low-20s.

A bit of snow helped to end the month of January. Light to occasionally steady snow began between 11 PM on the 29th and 1 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 29 - 32 degrees. The snow ended completely between 9 - 11 AM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 26 - 30 degrees.
Scattered light snow showers occurred between 12 - 3 AM on February 1st. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

Rain gradually mixed with, then changed over to all snow February 1st - 2nd. Periods of rain began to mix with some snow from 10 PM on the 1st - 1 AM on the 2nd as temperatures dipped to 33 - 36 degrees. A complete changeover to all snow occurred from 1 - 4 AM due to temperatures dipping near to just below 32 degrees. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 AM. Temperaturs by the end of the event settled down to 26 - 31 degrees.

Periods of rain gradually mixed with, then changed over to snow February 1st-2nd. Periods of rain from the evening of February 1st began to mix with snow from 1 - 4 AM on the 2nd as temperatures settled into the mid-30s. A changeover to all snow occurred by 4/5a before quickly ending from 5 - 7 AM. Temperatures dipped to 26 - 31 degrees by daybreak. Although the main system had already exited, a few flurries & isolated snow showers lingered as late as 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures continued to plummet to 23 - 27 degrees.

Brief period of snow during the morning of February 6th. A band of snow showers moved across the area between 8:30 - 10:30 AM Feb 6th.  Most of the snow showers were light, but there were brief bursts of moderate snow. Temperatures were between 25 - 28 degrees during the event.

Brief period of snow early on February 6th. A band of snow showers moved across the area between 9:30 - 11:30 AM Feb 6th. Most of the snow showers were light, but there were brief bursts of moderate snow. Temperatures were between 26 - 29 degrees.

Snow to brief sleet then a period of freezing rain occurred on February 7th. Light snow began between 8 and 10 AM on the 7th with temperatures of 21 - 25 degrees. The snow fell briefly moderate to heavy at times during the midday hours before mixing with a bit of sleet, then changing over to all freezing rain from 1 - 3 PM. Freezing rain continued into the evening before ending as brief light snow & flurries between 9 - 11 PM. Temperatures rose to 29 - 32 degrees. Due to the multiple precipitation types, accumulations were denser and therefore heavier than normal.

A shot of snow quickly changed over to a bit of sleet, then freezing rain and rain. A shot of light to moderate snow began between 8 - 10 AM on February 7th with temperatures of 26 - 31 degrees. The snow quickly changed over to sleet and freezing rain before transitioning to all freezing rain from 11 AM - 1 PM. As temperatures began to rise above the freezing mark, a changeover to all rain occurred from 3 - 5 PM. Due to the multiple precipitation types, accumulations were denser and therefore heavier than normal.
Scattered light snow showers & flurries developed between 1 - 4 PM on February 9th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.
Scattered light snow showers & flurries developed between 1 - 4 PM on February 9th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Scattered wintry mix showers of freezing rain with pockets of sleet & snow began between 3 - 6 AM on February 14th. The last of the showers dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures at the onset of 27 - 32 degrees rose near to just above 32 degrees by the end.

Scattered wintry mix showers of freezing rain with pockets of sleet & snow began between 3 - 6 AM on February 14th. The last of the showers dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures at the onset of 27 - 32 degrees rose near to just above 32 degrees by the end.

A thump of snow occurred from February 17th - 18th. Light to moderate snow began between 6 - 8 PM on the 17th with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. The snow continued into the overnight hours before lightening and tapering off completely from 4 - 6 AM on the 18th. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 26 - 30 degrees.

A quick thump of snow occurred overnight from February 17th-18th. Light snow began between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. The snow fell moderate to even heavy at times between 6 and 11 PM, allowing temperatures to dip near to just below 32 degrees. Light snow continued into the early pre-dawn hours of the 18th before ending from 1 - 4 AM on the 18th. Temperatures by the end of the event were 32 - 35 degrees.

Rain showes mixed with sleet and snow before changing completely over February 22nd. Rain showers the morning of the 22nd mixed with sleet and snow between 11 AM and 2 PM. Any mixture quickly changed to all snow from 2 - 4 PM. The snow came to an end between 5 and 7 PM. Temperatures began between 34 - 39 degrees, but fell to 32 - 34 degrees by the end of the event. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Offshore coastal system was still able to produce snow showers from March 4th-5th. What started as scattered rain showers during the late afternoon on the 4th quickly transitioned to snow showers from 4 - 6 PM. These periodic snow showers persisted into the overnight, dissipating completely from 7 - 9 AM on the 5th. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

Scattered snow showers began between 10 PM on the 4th - 1 AM on the 5th. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 1 - 4 AM. Temperatures generally held 33 - 36 degrees, but were capable of falling near to below freezing (29 - 32 degrees) during the steadier showers.

Second coastal system in a week brought periods of snow from March 7th-8th. Light areas of snow worked in between 2 - 4 AM on the 7th. Moderate to even heavy bands of snow finally pushed in from 11 AM - 1 PM, with snowfall rates upwards of 1-3"/hr occuring late afternoon into the early evening. Even lightning and thunder was reported at times under these very heavy bands. The snow lightened and tapered off to flurries going into the pre-dawn hours on the 8th before exiting completely from 4 - 7 AM. Temperatures during the entire event hovered between 32 - 35 degrees. It was windy, as well, with gusts of 25 - 35 mph.

Another Nor'easter pounded the western section of the state March 6th-8th. Intermittent light snow showers & flurries began to work in from 9 PM - Midnight on the 6th with temperatures of 34 - 38 degrees. These snow showers began to pick up in frequency from 1 - 3 AM on the 7th as temperatures dipped to 32 - 37 degrees. Moderate to even heavy bands of snow finally pushed in from 10 AM - 1 PM, briefly mixed with rain until intensity was able to overcome the marginal temperatures and allow for all snow. Even lightning and thunder was reported at times under these very heavy bands that produced 1-3"/hr rates. The snow lightened before exiting from 2 - 5 AM on the 8th. It was windy, as well, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph.

Periodic scattered snow/sleet/rain showers began between 5 - 8 AM on March 9th. The last of the wintry mix showers dissipated completely from 4 - 7 AM on the 10th. Temperatures at night were 27 - 32 degrees, then rose upwards of 35 - 40 degrees during the middle of the day.

Periodic scattered snow/sleet/rain showers began between 5 - 8 AM on March 9th. The last of the wintry mix showers dissipated completely from 4 - 7 AM on the 10th. Temperatures at night were 27 - 32 degrees, then rose upwards of 35 - 40 degrees during the middle of the day.

Third Nor'easter in a month impacted the state from March 13-14th. Light snow developed between 12 - 2 AM on the 13th with temperatures of 33 - 37 degrees. The snow fell moderate to heavy at times beginning 7 - 10 AM, resulting in up to 1"/hr rates. The snow lightened up after 2 PM, but did not taper off completely until 7 - 10 PM. Temperatures fell to 27 - 32 degrees by the end of the event. Winds were gusty as well, at 30 - 40 mph.

Third coastal system for March brought heavy snow and gusty winds. Light snow mixed with a little rain at the onset developed between 9 PM - Midnight on the 12th. The snow fell briefly moderate to heavy at times between 6 - 9 AM on the 13th. The snow lightened up and became intermittent from Noon - 2 PM, but did not taper off completely until 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 33 - 38 degrees throughout the event. Winds were gusty as well, at 25 - 40 mph.

Scattered snow squalls & intermittent light snow occurred from March 14th-15th. Scattered snow showers and squalls worked in between 3 - 6 PM on the 14th. Although the squalls exited completely from 6 - 9 PM, some lingering areas of intermittent flurries & very light snow persisted until 12 - 3 AM on the 15th. Temperatures fell from 34 - 39 degrees at the onset to near 32 by the end of the event.

Scattered snow squalls & intermittent light snow occurred from March 14th-15th. Scattered snow showers and squalls worked in between 3 - 6 PM on the 14th. Although the squalls exited completely from 6 - 9 PM, some lingering areas of intermittent flurries & very light snow persisted until 12 - 3 AM on the 15th. Temperatures fell from 34 - 39 degrees at the onset to near 32 by the end of the event.

Coastal storm #4 clipped the region with some light snow from March 21st-22nd. Light snow developed between 4 - 6 PM on the 21st. The snow fell intermittently at times before tapering off completely from 8 - 10 AM on the 22nd. Temperatures hovered in the mid-to-upper 30s during the entire event.

Late March storm brought steady snow & even some pockets of sleet to the region. Intermittent light snow with pockets of sleet began between 3 - 6 AM on the 21st, but took until mid-morning to truly become steady and widespread everywhere, even falling moderately at times. The snow continued into the overnight, ending competely from 4 - 7 AM on the 22nd. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the majority of the event, though did dip a degree or two below freezing under the steadiest snow within the interior.

A late season storm brought some snow on April 2nd. Light snow began between 3 - 5 AM on the 2nd with temperatures initially in the mid-30s. Temperatures quickly fell below freezing (27 - 32 degrees), especially as the snow became steady to heavy from 6 - 11 AM. Thereafter, the snow lightened before ending completely from 11 AM - 1 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s. . Due to it being very late in the season, pavements generally were warmer, resulting in variability in accumulation on them.

Early April snow impacted the southwestern portion of the state on the 2nd. Light snow began between 4 - 6 AM on the 2nd with temperatures of 35 - 40 degrees. As the snow became steady to even heavy, especially between 5 AM & Noon, temperatures quickly plummeted to 27 - 32 degrees. Thereafter, the snow lightened up before ending Noon - 2 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s.
Period of snow (mixed with rain at times) began between 8 - 11 AM on the 6th. The last of the wet flakes dissipated from 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures held in the mid-to-upper 30s.
Period of snow (mixed with rain at times) began between 8 - 11 AM on the 6th. The last of the wet flakes dissipated from 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures held in the mid-to-upper 30s.

Snow mixed in with the rain on April 10th. A snow/rain mix began between 5 - 7 AM on the 10th. While the lower elevations and city areas were more rain than snow, areas in the higher elevations in suburban & rural areas hung onto more snow. A transition to all rain occurred from Noon - 2 PM. Temperatures held 33 - 38 degrees throughout the event. . Accumulations were confined to colder/grassy surfaces due to marginal temperatures.

Very late season wintry storm impacted the northern half of the state April 15th-16th. Scattered freezing rain and sleet showers with a few pockets of snow & plain rain began between 7 - 9 PM on the 15th. The last of the wintry mix was able to transition to all plain rain showers from 5 - 8 AM on the 16th. While temperature at the onset were 32 - 35 degrees, they dipped to 29 - 32 degrees for majority of the event, then rose back above freezing during the early morning on the 16th.
A rain, sleet, and snow mix developed between 4 - 7 AM on the 19th. The last of the wintry mix exited from 7 - 10 AM. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

A warm front brought light snow and flurries to the region on December 18th. Light snow and flurries began between 2 - 5 AM on the 18th. Any lingering flakes dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Powerful coastal system brought occasional snow and sleet from March 2nd-3rd. Snow and sleet began to mix in at times with the rain from 4 - 7 AM on March 2nd. This variable wintry mix switched back and forth between rain and snow/sleet throughout the day, and was dependent on the intensity of precipitation as well as elevation. While the main system exited from 5 - 7 PM, a few flurries and occasional light snow showers lingered as late as 11 PM - 2 AM going into the 3rd. Temperatures throughout the event hovered in the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds were exceptionally strong as well, frequently gusting 45 - 65 mph.

Storm System Brings Wintry Mix December 12th. Light snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM December 12th with temperatures ranging from 28 - 30 degrees. As warmer air moved into the area, the precipitation changed to a mix of freezing rain and sleet after 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM. Temperatures climbed to 34 - 35 degrees by 2:00 - 3:00 PM, changing any wintry precipitation to plain rain.

Storm System Brings Wintry Mix December 12th. Light snow showers entered the area between 7:00 and 9:00 AM December 12th with temperatures ranging from 28 - 30 degrees. As warmer air moved into the area, the precipitation changed to a mix of freezing rain and sleet after 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM. Temperatures climbed to 34 - 35 degrees by 2:00 - 3:00 PM, changing any wintry precipitation to plain rain.

Storm System Brings Wintry Mix December 12th. Light snow showers entered the area between 5:00 and 7:00 AM December 12th with temperatures ranging from 28 - 30 degrees. As warmer air moved into the area, the precipitation changed to a mix of freezing rain and sleet after 12:00 to 1:00 PM. Temperatures climbed to 34 - 35 degrees by 2:00 - 3:00 PM, changing any wintry precipitation to plain rain.

Brief Mix of Rain and Freezing Rain January 22nd. A brief mixture of rain and freezing rain moved through the area between 12:00 and 4:00 AM January 22nd with temperatures near 32. Any precipitation during the mid to late morning hours fell as plain rain with temperatures in the mid 30s.

Mix of Rain and Freezing Rain January 22nd. A mix of light freezing rain and rain entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM January 22nd. Intermittent periods of light freezing rain and drizzle continued through the morning hours, before tapering off during the early afternoon. Another round of rain and freezing rain moved through between 4:00 and 10:00 PM that evening. Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees throughout the event. Note: Additional icing that occurred on January 23rd will be covered in a second report.

Rain Ends as Brief Period of Freezing Rain. Light rain showers moved through during the daytime on January 22nd with temperatures above freezing. As colder temperatures worked in during the evening, the rain ended as a brief period of freezing rain with temperatures near 32. Note: Additional icing that occurred on January 23rd will be covered in a second report.
Warm Front Brings Brief Period of Snow . A period of snow moved through the area between 12:00 and 3:00 AM February 1st with temperatures ranging from 27 - 30 degrees.
Warm Front Brings Brief Period of Snow . A period of snow moved through the area between 1:00 and 3:00 AM February 1st with temperatures ranging from 27 - 30 degrees.

Warm Front Brings a Few Periods of Snow . A period of snow moved through the area between 12:00 and 3:00 AM February 1st. After a brief lull, another round of snow moved through between 5:00 and 8:00 AM that same morning. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 31 degrees throughout the event.
Periods of Light Snow February 9th. Periods of light snow moved through the area between 1:00 and 7:00 PM February 9th. Temperatures ranged from 26 - 30 degrees.
Brief Snow Showers February 9th. A few brief snow showers moved through the area between 9:00 PM February 9th and 12:00 AM February 10th. Temperatures ranged from 27 - 31 degrees.

Scattered Snow Showers and Flurries March 9th. A few scattered snow showers aand flurries moved through the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM March 9th. After a break in the snow, another batch of snow showers and flurries moved through between 3:00 and 6:00 PM that evening. Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s for the first batch of snow showers, but rose to 32 - 35 during the second batch.

Scattered Snow Showers and Flurries March 9th. A few scattered snow showers and flurries moved through the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM March 9th. After a break in the snow, another batch of snow showers and flurries moved through between 1:00 and 7:00 PM that evening. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 30 degrees for the first batch of snow showers, but rose to 32 - 35 during the second batch.
Snow Shower and Flurries March 9th. After a few flurries during the morning, a brief snow shower moved through the area between 7:00 and 9:00 PM March 9th. Temperatures were in the mid 30s.

Weak Storm System Brings Light Snow April 10th. A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 4:00 and 6:00 AM April 10th. The steady snow continued through 1:00 to 3:00 PM that afternoon. Temperatures began between 30 - 32 degrees, but rose to 35 - 37 degrees by the end of the event.
Few Snow Showers April 10th. A few scattered snow showers moved through the area between 11:00 AM and 3:00 PM April 10th. Temperatures were in the mid 30s.
Snow Showers and Flurries December 16th. A few flurries and snow showers moved through the area between 12:00 and 5:00 PM December 16th. Temperatures ranged from 24 - 28.

Freezing Rain Changes to Plain Rain January 23rd.
