After a few patches of freezing drizzle/sprinkles moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 AM January 23rd, a steadier mix of rain and freezing rain developed during the late morning hours. The mixture gradually changed to plain rain between 1:00 and 3:00 PM that afternoon. Temperatures were steady between 30 - 32 during the icing, but quickly rose into the 40s by the afternoon.

Significant Icing Event January 23rd. After a few patches of freezing drizzle/sprinkles moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 AM January 23rd, a steadier freezing rain developed during the late morning hours with temperatures ranging from 29 - 32 degrees. The freezing rain continued through the early afternoon, falling heavily at times. The heavy intensity of the rain resulted in multiple rounds of re-icing. The precipitation gradually changed to plain rain between 2:00 and 4:00 PM that afternoon with temperatures rising into the mid 30s.

Rain Ends as Wet Snow April 7th. Periods of light rain ended as some wet snow showers between 3:00 and 7:00 AM April 7th. Temperatures began between 34 - 37 degrees, but fell to near 32 by the end of the event.
Brief Snow Shower April 9th. A few flurries and snow showers moved through the area between 12:00 and 3:00 AM April 9th. Temperatures ranged from 29 - 32 degrees.
Ocean Effect Snow Showers. A few ocean effect snow showers moved through the area between 6:00 and 11:00 AM January 1st. Temperatures ranged from 5 - 10 degrees.

Ocean Effect Snow Showers/Flurries January 14th. A few ocean effect snow showers and flurries entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM January 14th. The snow continued intermittently through the day, before ending between 3:00 and 5:00 PM that afternoon. Temperatures were steady in the low to mid 20s throughout the event.

A Weekend Snowstorm For New England. A widespread snowfall occurred over much of New Hampshire this past weekend as low pressure developed off Cape Cod.  Snow began across the area between 11 AM - 2 PM on December 9th.  The snow continued through the afternoon and into the overnight before tapering off between 2 - 5 AM on December 10th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 32 throughout the event.

Snow, Then A Wintry Mix. Snow developed across the area between 3 - 6 AM on December12th as low pressure approached New England.  The snow continued through the morning before mixing with and changing to sleet and some freezing rain between 1 - 3 PM.  The sleet and freezing rain then changed back to a another period of snow before ending 5 - 7 PM later on the 12th.  Temperatures were in the mid and upper 20s when the snow began then rose to near 32 degrees as the snow changed to sleet and freezing rain.

Afternoon Snow Showers. Flurries and scattered snow showers moved across parts of central and southern New Hampshire between 2 - 7 PM on December 16th.  Temperatures were mainly in the low to mid 20s.

A Wintry Mix For Southern New Hampshire. Areas of light snow developed across the regions 3 - 6 AM on December 18th.  The snow fell on and off through the day before mixing with and changing to sleet and freezing rain during the evening hours later on the 18th.  The wintry mix came to an end by Midnight on December 19th.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s when the snow began, then climbed into the low 30s before the precipitation exited the area.

More Snow For New Hampshire. Snow developed across southern New Hampshire between 4 - 7 AM on December 22nd as low pressure and a warm front approached New England.  The snow fell at varying intensities (along with a few breaks) through the day and into the evening (mixed with sleet at times) before tapering off between 7 - 10 PM later on the 22nd.  . This was followed by a period of light sleet then freezing rain that developed after 4 AM on December 23rd and continued into the morning, but this will be covered in another Certified Snowfall Total report.  . Temperatures were in the low to mid teens when the snow began, then climbed into the mid and upper 20s by the time the snow ended.

Freezing Rain For Southern New Hampshire. As overnight snow exited the area, precipitation returned as freezing rain 4 - 7 AM on December 23rd.  The freezing rain fell at varying intensities on and off through the day before ending or changing to plain rain 3 - 6 PM later on the 23rd.  Temperatures started out in the mid to upper 20s early on the 23rd then climbed to 32 - 35 degrees later in the afternoon as the precipitation ended.

A White Christmas For New Hampshire. Snow developed across the area between 11 PM on December 24th and 2 AM, December 25th.  The snow fell at varying intensities into the morning before tapering off 9 AM - Noon later on the 25th.  Also, additional snow showers fell across the area during the evening hours of the 25th.  Temperatures ranged 20 - 25 degrees throughout the storm.  Also, there was some blowing and drifting of the snow as the wind gusted over 30 mph, especially during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 25th.
Some Daytime Light Snow. A period of light snow and flurries fell across the area between 9 AM - 3 PM on December 29th.  It was very cold as temperatures ranged between 0 to 10 degrees.

Some Daytime Light Snow. A period of light snow and flurries fell across parts of central and southern New Hampshire between 10 AM - 3 PM on December 30th.  Temperatures ranged from 5 to 15 degrees across the area.

Strong Nor'easter For New Hampshire. A strong nor'easter produced widespread snowfall across New Hampshire.  After a brief period of flurries, snow developed over the area between 6 - 9 AM on January 4th.  The snow continued, heavy at times (snow rates peaked at 2 - 3" per hour), through the morning and afternoon before tapering off 7 - 10 PM later on the 4th.  Additional flurries fell during the overnight and into the early morning hours of January 5th.  Also, winds gusted over 40 - 50 mph creating blizzard-like conditions.  Temperatures ranged 20 - 26 degrees throughout the entire storm before falling into the teens by the morning of the 5th. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Afternoon Light Snow. A period of light snow moved across southern New Hampshire between 2 - 7 PM on January 8th.  There was some sleet and rain mixed in as well.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

More Snow For Southern New Hampshire. A slow moving storm system produced another widespread snowfall across southern New Hampshire.  Flurries and some light snow showers fell during the late afternoon hours of January 16. th. , but a steadier snow developed 7 – 10 PM later that evening.  The snow fell at varying intensities (including some pockets of heavy snow) through the overnight and morning hours of January 17. th. before tapering off to flurries during the early afternoon.  A final “band” of snow moved through towards evening before exiting the area 7 - 9 PM later on the 17. th. .  Temperatures ranged 28 – 33 throughout the event.

Significant Ice Across Southern New Hampshire. First, a period of very light snow and sleet fell across the area between 2 – 6 AM on January 22. nd. with temperatures ranging 30 – 32 degrees.  After warming above freezing, intermittent plain rain and drizzle continued throughout the day.  However, temperatures fell into the 28 - 32 degree range later in the evening of the 22. nd. .  This allowed for periods of light freezing rain (mixed with sleet at times) to fall into the early morning hours of January 23. rd. .  After a break, steady freezing rain entered the area between 8 – 10 AM with temperatures remaining 28 - 32 degrees. The freezing rain continued into the early afternoon, falling heavily at times. The heavy intensity of the rain resulted in multiple rounds of re-icing and significant ice build up. The precipitation gradually changed to plain rain between Noon - 2 PM later on the 23. rd. as temperatures climbed into the mid 30s.

Period of Snow the morning of February 1st. After a few scattered flurries and light snow showers developed between 1-4 AM, widespread snow started 3-6 AM. This period of steady, but light snow continued until 9-11 AM. Temperatures were 26 - 30 degrees.

Overnight Rain To Light Snow. Rain showers developed over the area around Midnight on February 2nd.  However, as a cold front pushed across the region, the rain changed to snow between 2 - 4 AM.  Periods of light snow continued into the morning before ending 7 - 9 AM later on the 2nd.  Temperatures were in the low 30s when the rain changed to snow, then fell into the mid and upper 20s as the snow tapered off.
Overnight Snow Shower. Scattered flurries along with a brief snow shower streaked across the area between 2 - 4 AM on February 4th.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s.
Morning Snow Showers. Flurries along with a few light snow showers moved across the area between 9 AM - Noon on February 6th. Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s.

Snow to Wintry Mix Event. Snow began 10:30 - 11:30AM on the 7th and quickly turned moderate to heavy. This snow continued through the afternoon, before turning to a wintry mix of brief sleet, then freezing rain by 3 - 5PM. Freezing rain, heavy at times continued into the evening before ending as light snow again between 8 - 10PM. Temperatures through the event held 26 - 31 degrees. The changing of precipitation types made this a very dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.
Overnight Snow Showers. A period of light snow showers fell across the area between 9 PM, February 9th and 2 AM, February, 10th.  Temperatures ranged 25 - 30 degrees.

Low Pressure Brings Overnight Snowfall. Snow developed across the area between 8 - 10 PM on February 17th.  The snow quickly became steady, then fell heavy at times overnight as snowfall rates reached 1" per hour.  It tapered off between 6 - 8 AM on February 18th.  Temperatures ranged 25 - 30 degrees throughout the event.

Snow falls across southern New Hampshire 2/22/2018. . Precipitation moved into the region between 12:00 and 2:00 PM on Feb 22nd, starting as a rain-snow mix before quickly changing over to snow. Snow fell moderately at times with snow rates of up to 0.5" per hour, with snow ending between 4:00 and 5:00 PM. Temperatures during the event hovered between 29 and 32 degrees.

A Period Of Snow, Then Sleet And Rain . Snow arrived across the area between 6:30 - 7:30 AM on February 25th. The snow continued for about 1 - 2 hours before mixing with rain and sleet at times. By 11 AM, the mixed precipitation turned to all rain. Temperatures during the wintry part of the event event held 30 - 33 degrees, then climbed into the mid 30s by early afternoon.
A Brief Wintry Mix. A period of light snow, sleet, and rain fell across the area between 3 - 6 AM on March 2nd. Temperatures ranged 32 - 35 degrees during the wintry mix before changing to rain.
Overnight Light Snow. Periods of light snow and flurries fell across the area between Midnight and 6 AM on March 5th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

Major Coastal Storm March 7 - 8th. After a few flurries fell early on the 7th, between 12 - 4AM, a lull occurred most of the day. Steady snow built in between 2 - 4PM, quickly turning moderate to heavy. Snow continued through the night and into the 8th, with the peak of the storm between 5PM - 5AM where 1 - 2" per hour snowfall occurred. Snow lingered much of the daytime of the 8th, generally light to moderate intensity before ending 4 - 7PM. Temperatures during the event were mainly 30 - 32 degrees, then rose to 32 - 35 during the daytime of the 8th. Winds gusted to 25 - 35 mph at times.

Evening And Overnight Snow Showers. Intermittent flurries and scattered snow showers streaked across the area between 4 - 9 PM on March 9th.  This was followed by another round of light snow showers between 3 - 6 AM on March 10th.  Temperatures ranged 31 - 34 degrees.

Another major coastal storm March 13 - 14th. Initial flurries and occasional light snow showers began late evening on March 12th with temperatures near 35 degrees. This transitioned to a steadier snow by 3 - 5 AM on the 13th, as temperatures settled below 32 degrees.  The snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 8 AM - 8 PM as snowfall rates reached 2 - 4" per hour within the heaviest snow bands. The main area of snow ended by Midnight of March 14th, however, light snow lingered through the remainder of the overnight into the morning of the 14th before ending 9 AM - Noon. Temperatures held 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall and winds gusted to 20 - 35 mph.
Overnight Snow Showers. Occasional flurries and scattered light snow showers moved across the area between 11 PM of March 14th and 4 AM of March 15th.  Temperatures ranged 31 - 34 degrees.
Morning Light Snow. Periods of light snow and flurries fell across the area between 4 - 10 AM on March 22nd.  Temperatures ranged from 30 - 34 degrees.

Overnight Snow Showers. After some flurries during the evening of March 24th, snow showers developed across the area between 11 PM - 1 AM.  The snow showers fell intermittently through the overnight before ending 6 - 8 AM on March 25th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 34 degrees.  There were some additional snow showers that returned during the afternoon later on the 25th.

April Morning Snowfall. A steady, light snow developed over the area between 6 - 8 AM on April 2nd.  The snow fell through the morning, briefly moderate at times, before ending 11 AM - 1 PM.  Temperatures ranged 29 - 33 degrees.  Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

More April Snow. Snow developed across the area between 11 AM - 1 PM on April 6th.  The snow fell moderate to even briefly heavy at times before tapering off between 4 - 6 PM later in the afternoon.  Temperatures were in the mid to upper 30s when the snow began, then fell to 32 - 34 degrees during the snowfall.  Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Daytime Snow Showers. Flurries and along with a few rain and snow showers fell during the afternoon hours of April 10th.  This was followed by a band of scattered snow squalls that moved across the area between 5 - 7 PM later on the 10th.  Temperatures were in the upper 30s to near 40 degrees during the afternoon, but fell to 33 - 35 degrees by evening.  . Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Morning Wintry Mix. A mix of mainly light sleet and freezing rain developed across the area between 3 - 5 AM on April 15th.  The wintry mix fell intermittently through the morning before tapering off 9 - 11 AM later on the 15th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 30 degrees.

Overnight Wintry Mix. A mix of sleet and freezing rain developed across the area between 8 - 10 PM on April 15th.  The wintry mix fell intermittently through the night (also mixed with snow at times) before changing to just rain between 5 - 7 AM on April 16th.  Temperatures ranged 29 - 33 degrees.

Morning Wintry Mix. A period of snow, mixed with sleet and rain at times, moved across southern New Hampshire between 8 - 11 AM on April 19th.  Temperatures ranged 33 - 36 degrees.  Due to warmer ground temperatures, accumulations were mainly confined to colder and non-paved surfaces.

First Widespread Snowfall of the Season on December 9th. A coastal system moved up the coast and brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent pockets of light snow first began between 7-10 AM as temperatures fell from the mid 30s down to 30-34 degrees. Snow became steady between 10am-2pm and continued light to moderate through the day as temperatures settled and held in the lower 30s. Snow generally turned lighter into the evening before completely ending between 11PM-2AM into December 10th as temperatures fell into the mid-upper 20s overnight. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

First Widespread Snowfall of the Season on December 9th. A coastal system moved up the coast and brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent pockets of light snow first began between 8-10 AM as temperatures fell from the mid 30s down to 30-34 degrees. Snow became steady between 10am-2pm and continued light to moderate through the day as temperatures settled and held 28-32 degrees. Snow generally turned lighter into the evening before completely ending between 10PM-Midnight as temperatures fell into the mid-upper 20s overnight. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

December 11 Early AM Snow Showers . With temperatures ranging from 30-34 degrees, scattered snow showers, briefly steady at times, moved through the region between 3-6am on the morning of December 11th. After snow showers exited, temperatures rose into the upper 30s to 40 during the afternoon.

Snow with Clipper System Late December 13th into 14th. Starting 10pm-12am from December 13th into the 14th a clipper system brought snow into the region. Snow was light to moderate overnight into December 14th as temperatures ranged between 23-30 degrees. Snow became intermittent after 1-3am, lulling to flurries at times. Any lingering flurries and snow showers came to an end between 6-8am as temperatures held 23-30 degrees. After snow ended, temperature rose to 35-40 degrees during the afternoon with wind gusts 20-30 mph.

Snow with Clipper System Late December 13th into 14th. Starting 10pm-12am from December 13th into the 14th a clipper system brought snow into the region. Snow was light to moderate overnight as temperatures ranged between 22-27 degrees. Snow became intermittent towards pre-dawn, lulling to flurries at times. Any flurries and areas of snow exited 6-8am as temperatures held 22-27 degrees. After snow ended, temperature rose into the lower 30s during the afternoon with wind gusts 20-25 mph.

Snow with Clipper System Late December 13th into 14th. Starting 8-11pm from December 13th a clipper system brought snow into the region. Snow was light to moderate overnight into December 14th as temperatures ranged between 24-30 degrees. Snow became intermittent after 1-3am, lulling to flurries at times. Any lingering flurries and snow showers came to an end between 6-9am as temperatures held 24-30 degrees. After snow ended, temperature rose into the upper 30s to lower 40s during the afternoon with wind gusts 20-30 mph.

Coastal Storm Brings Accumulating Snow on December 15. As a coastal storm developed out to sea, snow quickly developed between 12-3 PM on December 15th, and became steady during the late afternoon and evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate to heavy snow. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s, but settled into the mid 20s as snow became steady. The snow came to an end between 6-9 PM. After snow ended, temperatures fell into the upper teens to lower 20s overnight.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow on December 15. As a coastal storm developed out to sea, snow quickly developed between 1-3 PM on December 15th, and became steady during the late afternoon and evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the mid-upper 20s, but settled into the low-mid 20s as snow became steady. The snow came to an end between 6-8 PM. After snow ended, temperatures fell into the upper teens to lower 20s overnight.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow on December 15. As a coastal storm developed out to sea, snow overspread the area between 1-4 PM on December 15th, and became steady during the late afternoon and evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s, but settled into the mid 20s as snow became steady. The snow tapered to flurries and came to an end between 6-9 PM. After snow ended, temperatures fell into the upper teens to lower 20s overnight.

Clipper System Brings Snow on December 30th. With temperatures in the upper teens, light snow and flurries developed over the region between 6-9am on December 30th as a clipper system moved through the region. Temperatures remained steady as light, to at times steady, snow continued into the morning. Between 8am-12pm, a heavier band of snow developed producing 0.5-1" per hour rates. Between 12-4pm, snow tapered to flurries and ended with temperatures ranging from 20-25 degrees.

Clipper System Brings Snow on December 30th. With temperatures ranging from 14-19 degrees, light snow and flurries developed over the region between 6-9am on December 30th as a clipper system moved through the region. Temperatures ranged from 17-21 degrees as light snow continued into the morning before tapering to flurries and ending 1-4pm as temperatures held steady between 17-21 degrees.

Clipper System Brings Snow on December 30th. With temperatures ranging from 18-23 degrees, light snow and flurries developed over the region between 6-8am on December 30th as a clipper system moved through the region. Temperatures remained steady as light, to at times steady, snow continued into the morning. Between 11am-1pm, a heavier band of snow developed producing 0.5-1" per hour rates. Widespread snow quickly exited by 2pm, though intermittent snow showers and flurries remained through 4-7pm before ending with temperatures in the mid 20s.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind January 3rd into the 4th. With temperatures starting 28-32 degrees, areas of light snow arrived into the area between 11pm-2am on January 3rd into the 4th. Bands of steadier to heavy snow developed overnight as winds increased gusting to 30-40 mph. Temperatures fell into the low-mid 20s by daybreak as snow became heavy with 1- 3"/hr rates and blizzard-like conditions. Strong winds continued into the morning with gusts 40-50 mph as heavy snow continued with temperatures in the lower 20s. Snow became more intermittent and lighter between 1-4pm, with any areas of lingering snow coming to an end 5-8pm. Strong winds with gusts 35-50 mph continued into the overnight as temperatures held steady in the low to mid 20s. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind January 4th. Initial sporadic snow developed as early as 12-3 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the mid-upper 20s. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady 6-9 AM as temperatures cooled into the low-mid 20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Moderate to heavy snow, which at times fell at the rate of 1-2 inches per hour, continued through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 2-5 PM before ending between 6-8pm. In addition to the heavy snow were winds during the event that gusted 40-50 mph at times. Winds continued to gust into the overnight as temperatures help steady in the low-mid 20s. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind January 3rd into the 4th. With temperatures starting 28-32 degrees, areas of light snow arrived into the area between 9pm-12am on January 3rd into the 4th. Bands of steadier to heavy snow developed overnight as winds increased gusting to 30-40 mph. Temperatures fell to 25-30 degrees by daybreak as snow became heavy with 1-3"/hr rates and blizzard-like conditions. Strong winds continued into the morning with gusts 40-50 mph as heavy snow continued as temperatures fell into the mid-upper 20s. Snow became more intermittent and lighter between 12-3pm, with any areas of lingering snow coming to an end 5-8pm. Strong winds with gusts 35-50 mph continued into the overnight as temperatures fell into the low to mid 20s. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Disturbance Brings Freezing Rain and Sleet on January 8th. Between 2-5pm, areas of freezing rain and sleet arrived across the area with temperatures ranging 27-32 degrees on January 8th. A mix of freezing rain and sleet continued, intermittent at times into the evening, before ending between 8-10pm. Temperatures remained steady 27-32 degrees after precipitation exited.

Disturbance Brings Wintry Mix on January 8th. Between 1-3pm, a mix of sleet and freezing rain arrived across the area with temperatures ranging 25-30 degrees on January 8th. The sleet and freezing rain mix quickly transitioned to snow after 3pm before ending between 4-6pm. Temperatures remained steady 25-30 degrees after precipitation exited.

Disturbance Brings Freezing Rain on January 8th. Between 4-6pm, areas of rain arrived across the area with temperatures ranging 33-36 degrees on January 8th. As precipitation overspread the area, temperatures fell to 32-34 across all areas and in addition to a previous cold stretch rain changed over to freezing rain. Freezing rain then continued, intermittent at times into the evening, before ending between 9-11pm. Temperatures remained steady 32-34 degrees after precipitation exited.

Rain Changes to Snow During the Morning on January 17th. As a disturbance moved into the region from the west, areas of rain developed between 1-4am across the area on January 17th with temperatures ranging from 34-39 degrees. Cooler air and more moisture from a developing low pressure system off the coast caused rain to mix then transition to snow between 6-10am. Snow became steady at times before becoming intermittent and ending 12-3pm as temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees. Temperatures remained steady before falling into the mid 20s by sunset.

Rain Changes to Snow During the Morning on January 17th. As a disturbance moved into the region from the west, areas of rain developed between 1-3am across the area on January 17th with temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees. Cooler air and more moisture from a developing low pressure system off the coast caused rain to mix then transition to snow between 5-7am. Snow became steady at times into the morning before becoming light and intermittent and ending 12-3pm. Temperatures remained steady as snow ended before falling to 28-32 degrees by sunset.

Rain Changes to Snow on January 17th. As a disturbance moved into the region from the west, areas of rain developed between 1-4am across the area on January 17th with temperatures ranging in the upper 30s to lower 40s. Cooler air and more moisture from a developing low pressure system off the coast caused rain to mix then transition to snow between 6-10am. Snow continued before ending 1-4pm as temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees. Temperatures remained steady before falling into the mid 20s around sunset.

Coastal System Brings Areas of Snow January 29th-30th. Temperatures began in the upper 30s as precipitation arrived during the late evening on January 29th as rain showers. Rain showers mixed then transitioned to snow between 11pm-2am into January 30th as temperatures settled into the low 30s. Areas of light to steady snow continued overnight before tapering to intermittent flurries between 5-8am with temperatures in the low 30s. Intermittent flurries and snow showers continued into the afternoon as temperatures rose into the mid 30s before precipitation exited 3-6pm with temperatures falling into the 20s during the evening. Due to previous warmth, accumulation on paved surfaces was variable, and generally less than colder and grassy surfaces.

Coastal System Brings Areas of Snow January 30th. With temperatures starting in the mid to upper 30s, areas of light snow arrived between 12-3am on January 30th. Temperatures fell into the lower 30s as light to steady snow developed overnight and into daybreak hours. Areas of snow tapered to scattered and intermittent flurries and snow showers after 7am, which continued at times into the afternoon as temperatures rose to 33-37 degrees. Any lingering flurries and snow showers exited 4-7pm with temperatures falling into the 20s during the evening. Due to previous warmth, accumulation on paved surfaces was variable, and generally less than colder and grassy surfaces.

Coastal System Brings Areas of Snow Overnight January 29th-30th. Temperatures began in the upper 30s to 40 as precipitation arrived during the evening on January 29th as rain showers. Precipitation mixed then transitioned to snow between 10pm-2am into January 30th as temperatures settled into the low to mid 30s. Areas of light snow continued overnight before tapering to flurries and ending 3-6am with temperatures 30-35 degrees. Any additional snow showers that followed for the rest of the day will be handled in another report.

Rain Ends as Wet Snow Early on February 2nd. Periods of rain continued into the early morning on February 2nd as temperatures were in the mid 30s. As colder air rushed into the region rain mixed and changed briefly to a period of wet snow between 5-7am as precipitation ended. Temperatures quickly fell to 28-32 by daybreak as winds gusted to 20-30 mph.

Morning Snow Showers on February 5th. With temperatures starting 34-38 degrees, scattered snow showers and snow grains developed between 7-9am on February 5th as a cold front moved through the region. Temperatures fell to 30-33 degrees after snow showers exited with winds gusting 20-30 mph.

Mixed Precipitation Before Changing to Rain on February 7th. With temperatures 30-32 degrees, areas of mixed sleet and snow developed between 5-8 am on February 7th. By 9 am, the snow and sleet changed to freezing rain. As temperatures warmed to 34-38 degrees between 9 - 11am, the precipitation changed to plain rain.

Mixed Precipitation Before Changing to Rain on February 7th. With temperatures starting 28-32 degrees, areas of snow and sleet developed between 6 - 9 am on February 7th. Snow and sleet became briefly steady before changing to freezing rain 10 am-12pm as temperatures held 30-32 degrees. Precipitation changed to plain rain 1 - 4 pm as temperatures rose into the upper 30s to lower 40s with rain continuing into the evening. The changing precipitation types made this a more dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.

Snow Develops During the Evening on February 17th. With temperatures in the mid-upper 30s, areas of mixed rain and snow arrived across the area between 4-7pm on February 17th. Any rain changed to snow which was heavy with 1"/hr rates and caused temperatures to settle to 32-35 degrees. As warmer air arrived into the area, snow began to mix with and change to rain between 8-10pm before exiting 10pm-12am with temperatures ranging from 32-34 degrees through daybreak.

Low Pressure System Brings Heavy Snow on February 17th. Snow arrived across the area between 4-6pm on February 17th with temperatures 32-34 degrees. As a low pressure system strengthened off the coast, areas of heavy snow developed quickly into the evening with 1-2"/hr rates as temperatures settled to 30-33 degrees. Areas of heavy snow tapered to flurries and light snow before ending between 11pm-1am with temperatures 31-33 by daybreak.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind. A very strong Nor'easter brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. Precipitation started as rain (which began late on March 1) with temperatures in the upper 30s to lower 40s. Starting 8-11 AM on March 2, rain mixed with snow before changing over to all snow by the early afternoon. Snow fell steady to heavy at times before tapering down to flurries down to flurries and ending between 8-11pm. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 33 and 37 degrees and held in that range after precipitation ended. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40-50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind. A very strong Nor'easter brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. A good portion of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1) with temperature beginning in the upper 30s to lower 40s. Starting 7-11 AM on March 2, rain mixed with snow and sleet with combinations of rain, snow, and sleet continuing into the afternoon. Precipitation tapered down to flurries and sprinkles before ending between 7-10pm. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 34 and 38 degrees and held in that range after precipitation ended. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40-50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind. A very strong Nor'easter brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. A good portion of the precipitation fell as rain with temperatures starting in the upper 30s. Between 3-10 pm rain mixed and periodically changed to periods of snow. Any snow tapered down to flurries and sprinkles and ending 10pm-1am. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 34 and 38 degrees and held in that range after precpitation ended. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40-50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Rain and Heavy Snow with Powerful Coastal Storm March 6th into the 7th. . With temperatures starting in the mid-upper 30s, mixed rain and snow showers developed between 10 PM and 1 AM during the overnight of March 6th into the 7th. These mixed showers changed over to a few periods of all snow during the pre-dawn hours of March 7th. With temperatures in the mid 30s, combinations of rain and snow occurred through the morning to the midday until the powerful coastal storm strengthened to change the precipitation to predominately heavy snow between 1 and 3 pm. Snow fell at embedded 1-2"/hr rates with thunder and lightning, and wind gusts 30-40 mph. The snow tapered to intermittent flurries and light snow between 5-7pm which lingered through 8-10pm before completely ending. Temperatures settled to 30-34 degrees overnight. The combination of a dense, wet snow and windy conditions led to downed trees and wires.

Powerful Winter Storm on March 7. . Flurries and sprinkles during the late evening of March 6. th. transitioned to areas of snow between 12-3am on March 7th with temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees. Snow varied in intensity through the morning, even mixing with rain, as temperatures held steady. As a powerful coastal storm strengthened, snow became heavy between 12-6pm with embedded 1-2"/hr snowfall rates, thunder and lightning, and wind gusts 30-40 mph. Snow tapered to intermittent flurries and light snow between 6-8pm which lingered through 8-10pm before ending. Temperatures settled to 30-34 degrees overnight. The combination of a dense, wet snow and windy conditions led to downed trees and wires.

Rain and Snow with Powerful Coastal Storm on March 7th. . After rain occurred during the overnight and morning hours, cooler air filtered into the region on March 7th between 12-6pm causing rain to change to areas of snow, which was heavy at times. This caused temperatures to fall to 33-36 degrees during snowfall and with a powerful coastal storm off the coast winds gusted 40-55 mph with thunder and lightning. After bands of steady to heavy snow exited, any lingering flurries and light snow diminished 7-11pm with temperatures settling 32-36 degrees overnight.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow Early on March 13th. With temperatures ranging from 32-36 degrees, areas of mixed rain and snow showers which were around during the late evening on March 12th changed over to all snow between 12-3am on March 13th. Temperatures remained 32-36 degrees, as snow continued through the morning hours, steady to heavy at times, with winds gusting to 25-35 mph. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 10am-1pm with temperatures rising into the upper 30s to lower 40s through the afternoon.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow Early on March 13th. With temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees, areas of mixed rain and snow showers which were around during the late evening on March 12th changed over to all snow between 1-4am into the early morning on March 13th. Temperatures remained 33-36 degrees, as snow continued through the morning hours, steady at times, with winds gusting 20-30 mph. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 11am-2pm with temperatures rising into the upper 30s to lower 40s during the afternoon.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow Early on March 13th. With temperatures ranging from 34-38 degrees, areas of mixed rain and snow showers which were around during the late evening on March 12th changed over to all snow between 1-4am on March 13th. Temperatures remained steady as snow continued through the morning hours with winds gusting 25-35 mph. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 9-11am with temperatures rising into the 40s through the afternoon.Due to the marginal temperatures during the event, accumulation was mainly confined to colder surfaces.

Wintry Mix on March 20th. With temperatures in the mid 30s, areas of mixed rain and sleet moved into the region between 2-5pm on March 20th. In heavier bursts of precipitation, areas of sleet/snow developed through the afternoon causing temperatures to fall to 31-32 degrees. Any snow and sleet mixed with pockets of drizzle and freezing drizzle as precipitation became lighter before diminishing 8-11pm, with temperatures rising to 33-36 degrees into the overnight.

Late Day Sleet on March 20th. With temperatures ranging in the mid-upper 30s, scattered areas of sleet moved into the region between 3-8pm on March 20th. Any lingering sleet diminished by the evening.

Snow/Sleet Mix on March 20th. With temperatures in the mid-upper 30s, areas of mixed rain and sleet moved into the region between 9am-12pm on March 20th. As precipitation became steady, rain mixed and changed to snow and sleet during the afternoon as temperatures ranged from 33-35 degrees. Steady precipitation exited between 5-8pm, with lingering drizzle and flurries remaining into the evening as temperatures ranged from 34-37 degrees.

Heavy Snow on March 21st with Coastal Storm. Temperatures started 33-36 degrees with mixed snow, sleet, and rain around during the morning hours on March 21st. Any mix changed to snow 10am-1pm, which became steady to heavy into the afternoon and evening with embedded 2-4"/hr rates. Temperatures fell to 30-32 during the snowfall with wind gusts 25-35 mph. Heavy snow tapered to intermittent light snow and flurries between 12-3am. Any lingering flurries and light snow ended 3-6am on March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 32-34 degrees.

Snow with Late Season Coastal Storm on March 21st. Temperatures started 33-36 degrees as areas of snow and sleet starting 3-6am on March 21st. Any mix quickly changed to snow 6-9am, which continued into the afternoon. Snow intensity was variable during the day, with embedded steady to heavy snow at times. As the coastal storm developed east, snow remained into the overnight hours as temperatures fell and held 30-33 degrees. Snow tapered to intermittent light snow and flurries between 2-5am before ending completely 5-7am on March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 32-35 degrees. In addition, winds gusted 20-30 mph during the event.

Rain to Snow with Coastal Storm on March 21st. Temperatures started 34-38 degrees with areas of rain through the morning on March 21st. Snow mixed in at times through the early afternoon, before steadier precipitation arrived between 1-4pm as a coastal storm developed east. Snow fell steady to heavy at times through the evening before tapering to flurries and light snow 10pm-1am and ending 2-4am. Temperatures fell to 32-34 during snowfall, but rose to 33-35 degrees after snow ended. In  addition, winds gusted to 25-35 mph.

Early April System Brings Snow. With temperatures starting in the mid-upper 30s areas of light snow developed across the area starting 4-7am on April 2nd, which briefly mixed with rain initially. Light to moderate snow continued through the morning, with embedded heavier pockets, as temperatures settled to 32-34 degrees. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 9-11am with temperatures rising into the 40s during the afternoon.

Early April Winter Storm. With temperatures starting in the mid-upper 30s areas of light snow developed across the area starting 3-6am on April 2nd. Snow continued through the morning, becoming heavy with 1-2"/hr snowfall rates, as temperatures settled 32-33 degrees. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 9-11am with temperatures rising into the 40s during the afternoon.

Light Snow/Sleet Mix with System December 24th into 25th. As a system moved into the region, scattered areas of rain/snow/sleet developed between 7-10PM on December 24th. Temperatures started in the upper 30s but once precipitation began, fell to 33-36 degrees. Combinations of rain/snow/sleet remained overnight, changing to rain at times as temperatures held 33-36 degrees. The mix continued, most widespread between 4-7AM on December 25th. Scattered flurries remained through 9-11AM before ending, with temperatures rising into the mid-upper 30s for afternoon as winds increased and gusted 30-40 mph.

Late Afternoon and Evening Snow Showers on March 14th. With temperatures starting 37-42 degrees, scattered snow showers and flurries developed over the region starting 3-6pm. Snow showers continued into the evening hours, with some embedded steadier bursts as temperatures fell to 33-35 degrees. Snow showers exited between 9pm-12am with temperatures falling to 31-34 degrees overnight.

First Widespread Snowfall of the Season on December 8th and 9th. A coastal system moved up the coast and brought snow over the area on December 8th into the 9th. Flurries and intermittent pockets of light snow first began starting 6-9 PM on December 8th as temperatures fell from the upper 30s down to 33-35 degrees. Snow remained light and intermittent overnight as temperatures held 33-35 degrees. Starting 6-9am on December 9th, snow became moderate at times and remained light to moderate into the morning and afternoon as temperatures fell to 30-33. After 2pm, snow began to mix with rain and sleet at times with variable precipitation types as temperatures held 33-34 degrees. Any mix changed back to light to moderate snow before ending 12-3am into December 10th as temperatures fell into the upper 20s to lower 30 overnight. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Disturbance Produces Snow Showers and Squalls on January 30th. With temperatures 33-37 degrees, snow showers and flurries developed between 8-11am on January 30th. Embedded in snow showers, were snow squalls, which included steadier bursts of snow and wind gusts 20-30 mph. Temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees as snow showers continued into the afternoon. Any snow showers and flurries diminished 5-8pm with temperatures continuing to fall into the 20s during the evening.

Late Morning/Early Afternoon Snow Showers on February 2nd. With temperatures in the upper 20s, scattered snow showers and flurries moved through the area between 10am-1pm on February 2nd. Temperatures remained steady after snow showers exited as winds gusted 20-30 mph.

Returning snow showers on January 30th. After a coastal system affected Long Island earlier on January 30th, additional flurries and snow showers returned after 5 - 6 PM. Temperatures were initially 32 - 35 degrees before cooling falling into the mid-20s during the evening. Snow showers and flurries then diminshed by midnight. . Note: Snow that occurred before 5 PM with the coastal system was covered in a previous report.

Rain to snow event on February 2nd. Periods of rain developed during the evening on February 1st, with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. Rain continued into the early morning of the 2nd, mixing and changing to a steady wet snow by 4 - 6 AM as temperatures quickly cooled between 29 - 32 degrees. Snow was light to moderate in intensity, eventually ending by 7 - 9 AM. Temperatures continued to cool between 25 - 29 degrees through the morning with gusts up to 30 - 35 mph. Flurries and brief snow showers returned across the East End between 11 AM - 2 PM, with any lingering flurries ending by sunset.

Rain to snow event on February 2nd. Periods of rain developed during the evening on February 1st, with temperatures in the mid-30s. Rain then mixed and changed to a mainly wet snow by 1 - 3 AM on the 2nd as temperatures quickly cooled to 33 - 35 degrees. Snow was light but became moderate at times between 4 - 6 AM as temperatures fell below freezing. This then tapered off by 6 - 8 AM, with temperatures continuing to cool further into the mid-20s and winds gusting up to 30 - 35 mph.

Morning snow showers on March 9th. After a few pre-dawn flurries on March 9th, scattered snow showers developed between 5 and 8 AM. These then tapered off to flurries by 9 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 28 - 32 degrees during the event.

Late day flurries and snow showers on March 9th. After spotty flurries during the day on March 9th with temperatures in the upper 30s to 40 degrees, scattered snow showers briefly developed between 5 and 9 PM. Temperatures had settled between 32 and 37 degrees by the early evening. However, due to the marginal temperatures, most accumulation was found on colder/grassy surfaces

Wintry mix on December 12th. After a few flurries shortly after midnight on the 12th, mixed sleet, snow, and brief freezing rain in spots arrived 5 - 8 AM as temperatures held between 32 - 36 degrees. This continued into the morning, changing to all rain at times by mid-day and through the rest of the afternoon as temperatures warmed further into the mid-to-upper 30s. However, precip did change back to light snow as temperatures cooled to 30 - 34 degrees after 6 PM, eventually tapering off by 9 - 10 PM.

Early wintry mix on December 18th. Combinations of light snow and sleet moved through the region between 1 - 6 AM on the 18th. While the precipitation was in the region, temperatures were generally in the upper 20s and lower 30s.

Early freezing rain event on December 23rd. With temperatures between 30 - 33 degrees, a period of freezing rain and drizzle occurred between 2 - 8 AM as a system moved in from the south on December 23rd. This eventually changed to plain rain by 8 - 10 AM as temperatures warmed further into the mid-to-upper 30s, ending any icing threat.

Returning snow showers and flurries on December 25th. After a system departed early Christmas, flurries and scattered snow showers continued late morning into the afternoon with temperatures between 30 - 35 degrees and winds gusting up to 30 - 40 mph. A lull occurred by the mid-afternoon, before additional snow showers and flurries occurred between 5 -  9 PM. Flurries then lingered overnight with temperatures settling in the mid-to-upper 20s.

Wintry mix on December 24-25. Scattered showers of snow, sleet, and even brief freezing rain in spots developed between 8 - 11 PM on the 24th. Temperatures were initially in the mid-30s before settling to 30 - 33 degrees overnight into the 25th. Showers continued until steadier precipitation of mainly snow and sleet moved in between 4 - 8 AM. A few flurries and snow showers then lingered until 10 AM as temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds also gusted up to 30 - 40 mph through the morning.

Morning Snow on February 6th. Areas of snow moved through the region between 6 and 11 AM on February 6th. While most of the snow was light to moderate, there were occasional bursts of heavy snow in spots which resulted in quick coverings of all ground surfaces. While snow was in the region, the temperature was in the low to mid 20s.

Brief wintry mix to rain on February 4th. A mix of snow, sleet, and brief freezing rain fell between 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures cooled from the mid-to-upper 30s to between 32 - 35 degrees. Any wintry mix then transitioned to all rain after 3 - 6 PM as temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s.

Accumulating snow on February 9th. A light to moderate snow overspread the region between 11 AM - 1 PM on February 9th. Snow was steady into the afternoon with occasional bursts of heavier snow around sunset before tapering off to flurries by 6 - 8 PM. Temperatures were between 25 - 30 degrees during snowfall.

Early morning freezing rain on February 14th. An area of freezing rain and drizzle, mixed with sleet in spots, occurred between 3 - 7 AM on February 14th. Temperatures were between 28 - 32 degrees during the rain before warming into the mid-to-upper 30s after 9 AM.

Morning snow showers on March 16th. Snow showers occurred between 6 and 10 AM on March 16th. Some of these became briefly heavy for a time. Flurries then continued to linger afterwards before diminishing during the early afternoon. Temperatures were between 29 and 34 degrees during the event, eventually warming into the mid-to-upper 30s by the afternoon.

Disturbance brought accumulating snow on April 6th. Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 7 and 10 AM on April 6th with temperatures between 29 and 34 degrees. Snow briefly became heavy at times before temperatures warmed into the mid-to-upper 30s after 11 AM-12 PM, causing snow to mix and eventually changeover to rain in spots. All precipitation then quickly ended by 1 - 2 PM. Due to marginal temperatures, accumulations were confined to colder and grassy surfaces.

Late season snow and rain mix on April 10th. Areas of light snow mixed with rain in spots occurred between 3 and 10 AM on April 10th. A few non-accumulating flurries then continued to linger into the afternoon. Temperatures were between 32 and 37 degrees during the event before warming into the 40s. Accumulations were confined to colder/grassy surfaces due to marginal temperatures.
Late November Passing Rain / Snow Showers. Early on the morning of November 27th, some light snow mixed with rain fell intermittently from 4 - 8AM. Temperatures were 32 - 36 degrees.

Lake Effect Snow Showers Influence the Region. Some light scattered snow showers passed through the region on December 7th mainly, 5 - 10AM. After that some areas saw a few more scattered and light snow showers ending for good that night 6 - 8PM. Temperatures for the event were mild, 34 - 36 degrees.

December 9th Clipper System . On the afternoon of December 9th, a clipper system passing to the southeast brought snow to the region which began falling 12 - 2PM. The snow was mainly light with a few embedded steady periods which occurred in the evening. The event came to a close as the system moved out 9 - 11PM. Temperatures began near 32 degrees and fell to end the event 24 - 27.

Lengthy On & Off Lake Effect Snow Showers. Snow showers / flurries began to push their way back into the region the morning of the 10th, 7 - 9AM. The snow was light and intermittent falling in some spots throughout the afternoon and into the following morning, the 11th. It wasn't until late that morning that snow was a bit more consistent, from 11AM - 2PM. After a brief lull, the snow again picked up early on the 12th, 1 - 3AM. From there, snow persisted through 7AM, with anything falling after this timeframe covered in the following report. Temperatures during the day were 32 - 34 degrees, cooling to be 27 - 30 during the overnight periods.

Continued Lake Effect Snow Showers Influence the Region . Snow continued to fall on December 12th at 7AM becoming steady in areas into the early afternoon. From there, the snow transitioned to be mainly rain beginning 12 - 2PM with temperatures that were 32 - 34 degrees. That evening, it began to snow once again 5 - 7PM falling lightly and intermittently into the night and following morning, the 13th. Snow continued on and off in spots throughout the 13th as temperatures fell to be 16 - 19 degrees. It wasn't until the following morning, the 14th, that the scattered snow showers finally came to a close 8 - 10AM.

Mid-December Lake Effect Snow Showers. Scattered snow showers / flurries fell on December 15th beginning 9PM - 12AM and continued into the following day, the 16th, as the light snow tapered off 2 - 4PM. Temperatures for the event began 20 - 22 degrees and warmed to end 25 - 28.

Intermittent Snow Showers Dec. 20. Light and scattered snow showers began to influence the area the morning of December 20th, 4 - 6AM with temperatures 34 - 36 degrees. The snow fell intermittently in spots throughout the day ending for good that night 9 - 11PM with temperatures that had cooled to be 27 - 30.
December 18th Snowfall. Snow fell on and off on December 18th beginning 1 - 3AM and largely ended a few hours later, 11AM - 1PM. Temperatures began 10 - 14 degrees and warmed to finish 28 - 32.

Snow to Freezing Rain Event. Snow began between 1 - 3AM on the 22nd with temperatures around 20 degrees. Snow was light, and became intermittent through the morning and afternoon hours, with the steadier snow just to the north. Late in the day, some sleet began to mix in, with freezing rain showers following overnight. This resulted resulted in icy conditions with temperatures still in the 20s. Steadier freezing rain arrived early on the 23rd, and transitioned to mainly plain rain by Noon as temperatures most locations rose to 33 - 36 degrees. Rain ended in the evening.

Lake effect snow affected New York on December 24. th. and 25. th. . Snow developed between 9 PM and midnight on the 24. th. .  A steady period of light to occasionally moderate snow occurred.  Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s.  The snow tapered off between 10 AM and 1 PM on the 25. th. . Additional snow occurred on the 26. th. and will be discussed in the next report.

A disturbance produced another round of additional snow across New York on December 30. th. . Snow developed between 6 and 9 AM.  A steady period of light snow was observed for most of this event.  Temperatures ranged from 5 to 15 degrees.  The snow tapered off to scattered flurries after sunset and diminished completely between 6 and 9 PM.

Snowfall to Bring in the New Year. Scattered, light snow showers fell in the area beginning the morning of January 2nd, 2 - 4AM with temperatures -2 to 2 degrees. Snow was intermittent and light falling on and off in spots before mainly ending that afternoon 3 - 5PM with temperatures 8 - 12 degrees.

Coastal Storm Impacts the Region. Steady, light snow began to fall the morning of January 4th, 7 - 10AM, as a potent nor'easter traveled up the east coast. Snow quickly became more moderate after 12PM as winds picked up and blew the snow around with gusts reaching 25mph at times. That evening, the snow became light, tapering off to finish 9 - 11PM. Temperatures were near 15 - 19 degrees for the event.
Light and scattered snow flurries / showers fell the night of the 5th from 5 - 11PM with winds gusting 30mph and temperatures 2 - 6 degrees.

Light Snowfall January 7 - 8. Scattered snow showers began to influence the area late on January 7th, 9 - 11PM with temperatures 8 - 12 degrees. Snow was mainly light and intermittent falling in spots throughout the morning of the 8th with winds gusting to 25mph. That afternoon, snow largely clearing out from 2 - 4PM as temperatures warmed a bit to finish 22 - 25 degrees.

Intermittent Light Snow Jan 9. Light and scattered snow showers / flurries redeveloped early on January 9th, 1 - 4AM with temperatures 25 - 27 degrees. Snow was largely intermittent in nature falling in spots throughout the day before ending everywhere, 4 - 7PM that night. Temperatures finished a bit warmer, 30 - 32 degrees.

Arctic Front Brings Wintry Mix. As an arctic front began to influence the region late on January 12th, rain transitioned to freezing rain around midnight as temperatures, which were previously in the 50s, dramatically dropped to be near freezing, 30 - 34 degrees. Sleet began to mix in with the precipitation 1 - 3AM, along with embedded areas of snow. A sleet / snow mix fell that morning becoming moderate and a bit heavy in spots before becoming light and intermittent midday. From there, on and off snow showers persisted into the afternoon coming to a close that evening, 3 - 5PM. Winds were gusting to 30mph at times throughout the event causing blowing and drifting. When all was said and done, temperatures ended 16 - 20 degrees.

Mid-January Light Snow Showers. Scattered snow showers worked their way into the region the night of January 15th beginning 11PM - 1AM (the 16th). Snow was mainly light and intermittent tapering off that morning from 5 - 7AM. Temperatures were 11 - 15 degrees for the event.

Low Pressure Brings Persistent Snow. Steady snow redeveloped the morning of January 16th, 9 - 11AM. Snow was largely light but persistent as it fell steadily throughout the 16th and into the 17th with some embedded pockets of more moderate snow falling at times. It wasn't until the afternoon of the 17th that steady snow transitioned to be scattered snow showers beginning 2 - 4PM, and ending a few hours later 6 - 8PM. Temperatures began 27 - 30 degrees and fell throughout the event to finish 16 - 20.
Nighttime Snow January 18th. A lake effect band brought some light snow to the area the night of January 18th from 7 - 11PM with temperatures 20 - 23 degrees.

Cold Temps and Drizzle Produce Freezing Rain. Very light, patchy drizzle moved into the area early the morning of January 22nd and as temperatures were near freezing, 32 - 34 degrees, freezing rain occurred from 12 - 5AM resulting in some ice development. Anything falling after that was plain drizzle as temperatures rose into the mid 30s.
A few very light and scattered lake effect snow showers passed over the region the morning of January 24th between 6AM - 12PM with temperatures 26 - 28 degrees.
A period of snow occurred the afternoon of January 31st from 3 - 6PM with temperatures 25 - 27 degrees.

Late January Low Pressure Snowfall. A winter weather system brought snow to the region that began falling January 30th from 5 - 8AM with temperatures 22 - 25 degrees. Pockets of steady, more moderate snow worked into the area and fell at times throughout the morning with winds gusting to 25mph at times. Snow became overall light that afternoon largely ending 9 - 11PM with only a few lake effect snow showers lasting in spots overnight. The following morning, the 31st, any light snow showers ended for good 4 - 6AM with temperatures that had cooled to finish 15 - 17 degrees.

Cold Front Produces Early February Snow. After a few scattered, light snow flurries during the day of February 1st, a cold front came through bringing steady, light pockets of snow to the region which fell from 9PM - 3AM on the 2nd. Temperatures began in the mid 30s and quickly cooled to finish 26 - 28 degrees along with winds gusting 25mph at times throughout the event.

Superbowl Wintry Mix Event. On February 4th, snow worked into the region beginning 7 - 9AM with temperatures 32 - 34 degrees and winds gusting 25 - 30 mph causing blowing and drifting. Snow fell throughout the afternoon becoming more moderate around 4 - 7PM. From there, precipitation became a mix of rain, snow, sleet, and freezing rain, as temperatures held steady near or just above freezing. The mix tapered off just after midnight, the 5th, as a few lake effect snow showers set up. From there, a few snow showers passed through the region exiting 8 - 11AM with temperatures that had fallen to be 27 - 30 degrees.

System Brings Light Snow Feb. 6. Snow showers began the morning of February 6th, 7 - 9AM. Around noon, only light, lake effect flurries remained in spots which ended for good 4 - 6PM. Temperatures for the event were 18 - 22 degrees.

Winter Storm Followed by Lake Effect. A large scale weather system brought snow to the area beginning the morning of February 7th, 8 - 10AM, quickly becoming moderate and heavy in spots with temperatures 17 - 20 degrees. Pockets of moderate to heavy snow continued into the afternoon before returning to be mainly light snow between 1 - 3PM. As snow became light again, it transitioned to be a mix of sleet and freezing rain which fell with temperatures holding near 20 degrees, before tapered off that evening, 6 - 8PM as lake effect snow filled in behind the system. Any snow produced from the lake effect was light and scattered, falling intermittently before ending for good early the morning of the 8th, 1 - 2AM as winds began gusting to 25mph. Temperatures finished 20 - 23 degrees.

Snow throughout the Day Feb. 9. A warm front brought snow to the area beginning February 9th, 12 - 2PM. Snow was mainly light and scattered, tapering off to end 9 - 11PM. Temperatures for the event held steady 24 - 28 degrees.

Icy Conditions from Freezing Rain. A period of rain transitioned to light freezing rain from 10 PM Feb 10 - 1 AM Feb 11. A lull in the freezing rain occurred between 3 AM and 7 AM Feb 11, with another period of moderate freezing rain falling through 4:30 - 6:30 PM Feb 11. Temperatures held steady near freezing, 30 - 32 degrees for the majority of the event, falling to a low point of around 28 degrees around daybreak the 11th.

Weak Cold Front Produces Light Snow. After some morning rain showers, a weak cold front pushed through the area overnight February 16th, bringing light lake effect snow showers to the region which fell from 9 - 11PM. A few hours later, a brief returning flurry fell the morning of the 17th, 5 - 7AM. Temperatures began 32 - 34 degrees and cooled to finish in the upper 20s.

Fast-Moving System Produces Overnight Snow . On the night of February 17th, as a low pressure system tracked up the east coast, light snow began 6 – 8PM, quickly becoming steady. Snow continued into the early morning of the 18th and while mainly light in intensity, persisted with embedded pockets of steadier snow that fell for a few hours before quickly tapered off 4 – 6AM. After that, only a light flurry or two fell in spots before ending for good 8 – 10AM. Temperatures for the event began near freezing, 30 – 32 degrees, and fell a bit to finish 26 – 28.

A winter storm brings snow to the region on February 22. A winter storm impacted the area on February 22. nd. . Snow began to develop across the area between 9am-12pm and quickly became steady. Though it was light at the onset, it wasn’t long before periods of moderate to occasionally heavy snow made their way into the area and fell into the afternoon and evening. The snow tapered back off in intensity to flurries before ending between 3-6PM. Temperatures throughout the event were initially 33-36 degrees, but fell to 29-32 degrees in steadiest/heaviest snow.

Quick Shot of Freezing Rain. Light rain showers began the morning of February 23rd and as temperatures were 30 - 32 degrees, pockets of freezing rain occurred from 9AM - 1PM. However, due to preceding warmth, much of the icing was confined to colder, elevated surfaces. After that, as steadier precipitation arrived, temperatures warmed safely above freezing and precipitation became plain rain.

Morning Wintry Mix February 25th. Sleet began early the morning of February 25th, 3 - 5AM with temperatures 30 - 32 degrees. However, as day broke and temperatures began to rise, sleet mixed with light freezing rain which worked to transition to plain rain a few hours later between 10AM - 12PM as temperatures rose into the mid 30s.

Early March Nor'easter Dumps Snow. Rain quickly turned to steady snow the night of March 1st between 9 - 11PM with temperatures in the mid-upper 30s. In the coming hours, around 2 - 4AM, as temperatures cooled to be 32 - 34 degrees, moderate and heavy pockets of snow developed, and fell throughout the morning, falling heaviest around 7 - 9AM. By midday, snow became generally light again, tapering off the afternoon of the 2nd, 5 - 7PM with only some light snow and scattered snow showers ending by midnight. Temperatures held steady at 32 - 34 degrees to end the event. In addition, winds were gusty becoming 25 - 30mph at times throughout the storm.

Persistent Light Snow Showers March 4-5. Light and scattered snow showers moved into the region the morning of March 4th between 8 - 10AM with temperatures marginal, 34 - 36 degrees. Steadiest snow fell that afternoon between 12 - 5PM as temperatures dropped a few degrees to be near 32. After that, snow became scattered once again mainly ending 7 - 9PM despite some scattered, overnight flurries that completely exited by 5 - 7AM on the 5th with temperatures holding 30 - 32 degrees.

Another Nor'easter Triggers Persistent Snow Showers. Early on March 7th, a nor'easter brought snow to the region which began 1 - 3AM with marginal temperatures, 32 - 36 degrees. Snow was steady and fell moderately / heavily at times throughout the morning and afternoon, mainly 8 - 9AM, and again 2 - 6PM as temperatures hovered 31 - 33. After that, snow was mainly light but persistent, continuing at times throughout the night and into the 8th, becoming scattered after midnight. From there, snow showers fell intermittently throughout the day with a steadier snow shower occurring 2 - 8PM. Overall, snow tapered off 9 - 11PM as temperatures held near 30.

Upper Level Disturbance Produces Snow Showers. After a brief lull, flurries worked back into the area the morning of March 9th, 2 - 4AM with temperatures 27 - 30 degrees. Late morning, steadier snow worked into the region from 10AM - 12PM as temperatures rose into the mid 30s, 34 - 36, and winds gusted to 25mph at times. By 3 - 5PM, snow largely tapered off. That night, only a few scattered snow showers fell as a potent lake effect band set up to the west, mainly 3 - 5AM the morning of the 10th, and again around 8AM. Temperatures rose from an overnight low of 28 - 30 to finish 32 - 34 degrees.

Coastal System Produces Lengthy Snowfall. As yet another coastal system began influencing the region the night of March 12th, light snow showers began 7 - 9PM with temperatures 38 - 40 degrees. Snow became steady around midnight with temperatures falling to 32 in the predawn hours, 3 - 5AM. This continued into the afternoon as a few bands of moderate / heavy, lake enhanced snow formed over the region 3 - 5PM. A few hours later, 9 - 11PM, as temperatures fell 28 - 30, snow became light again with embedded pockets of steady snow falling overnight and into the morning of the 14th. Steady snow tapered to light and scattered snow showers midday as temperatures rose 32 - 36 and winds picked up gusting to 25mph at times. Continuing on and off into the night, light and scattered snow showers exits for good early on the 15th, 4 - 6AM, as temperatures remained steady near to above freezing.

Mid-March Snow Showers . A few scattered snow showers fell the night of March 16th between 7PM - 1AM (the 17th) with temperatures 25 - 30 degrees. After that, only a light flurry or two persisted into the morning ending by midday. Winds were a bit gusty, becoming 25 mph at times.

Late March Snow Showers. A few light snow showers passed through the region overnight March 24th - 25th between 9PM - 12AM and again 3 - 7AM. Overall, snow was light with temperatures 28 - 32 degrees.

Quick & Potent Disturbance Produces Snow April 2. Areas of light and steady snow worked through the region between 5 - 10AM as a potent winter weather system passed to the south. Temperatures for the event were 28 - 32 degrees during the event before warming into the mid to upper 40s that afternoon.
Early April Winter Weather. Rain mixed with some sleet and snow the morning of April 3rd between 10AM - 1PM becoming plain rain after. Temperatures for the event were 34 - 38 degrees.

Cold Front Triggers Scattered April Snow Showers . Light and scattered snow showers fell overnight on April 4th mainly between 8PM - 2AM the following morning, the 5th. After that only a light snow shower or two fell ending for good in the predawn hours of the 5th. Temperatures began in the mid 30s and cooled as a cold front came through, ending 25 - 30 degrees. Associated with the cold front, winds were gusting 25 - 35 mph.

Another Round of April Snow. A period of steady snow fell on April 6th between 8AM - 2PM as temperatures increased from 32 - 34 degrees into the upper 30s. After that, scattered rain showers fell at times throughout the afternoon, transitioning back to a period of snow as a cold front sunk through the area early on the 7th between 1 - 7AM with temperatures 28 - 32 degrees. Winds were a bit gusty during the event, briefly becoming 25mph at times.

Snow Showers April 8th. Widespread snow showers began midday on April 8th, 11AM - 1PM and fell throughout the afternoon. That evening, snow became intermittent and tapered off 8 - 10PM. Temperatures for the event were marginal, 32 - 36 degrees.

Late-Season Sleet and Freezing Rain Event. Scattered areas of sleet and freezing rain began the night of April 14th, 9 - 11PM becoming widespread after midnight, the 15th. Continuing throughout the early morning, precipitation fell as mainly freezing rain from 7 - 11AM, taking a break into the afternoon. Temperatures began 28 - 30 and rose by midday to be 34 - 36. It wasn't until later that evening that another round of rain worked back into the area and as temperatures fell 30 - 32 degrees, precipitation became freezing rain 6 - 8PM. Periods of freezing rain continued overnight and into the morning of the 16th, ending 3 - 5AM as temperatures again rose 34 - 36 prompting any precipitation after to fall as plain rain.
A mix of rain, snow and sleet fell on April 19th between 4 - 7AM with temperatures 34 - 38 degrees.

A potent early season winter storm on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow developed on the morning of December 9th between 8 and 10 AM with temperatures 32 – 35 degrees. The snow subsequently became steadier, and fell at a moderate rate through the early afternoon with temperatures that quickly fell below freezing, specifically 27 – 32 degrees. The snow continued into the evening between light and moderate rates, before ending completely between 10 PM and 12 AM, with temperatures that remained below freezing. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

A potent early season winter storm on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow developed on the morning of December 9th between 8 and 10 AM with temperatures 32 – 35 degrees. The snow subsequently became steadier, and fell at a moderate rate through the early afternoon with temperatures that quickly fell below freezing, specifically 27 – 32 degrees. The snow continued into the evening between light and moderate rates, before ending completely between 10 PM and 12 AM, with temperatures that remained below freezing. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Early morning December 11th snow showers. Flurries and snow showers moved through the area on the morning of the 11th, between 3 - 5 AM. Temperatures during the flakes were 31 - 35. After snow showers exited, temperatures rose into the upper 30s to low 40s during the afternoon.

Clipper brings snow on December 13 – 14th. Light snow overspread the area on December 13th between 8 – 10 PM with temperatures that were in the mid-upper 20s. The snow increased in intensity and became moderate at times quickly following the onset of snow. Later the snow became a bit more intermittent and showery in nature during the early morning hours on December 14th, before ending as a final steady round of light to moderate snow which pushed through 5 – 8 AM with temperatures warming to 30 – 33 degrees.

Clipper brings snow on December 13 – 14th. Light snow overspread the area on December 13th between 8 – 10 PM with temperatures that were in the low-mid 20s. The snow increased in intensity and became moderate at times quickly following the onset of snow. Later the snow became a bit more intermittent and showery in nature during the early morning hours on December 14th, before ending as a final steady round of light to moderate snow which pushed through 5 – 8 AM.

Quick hitting snow on December 15th. On the early afternoon of December 15th, steady snow quickly overspread the area between 12 – 2 PM, with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Soon after starting, the snow rapidly increased in intensity, with moderate to heavy snow impacting the area during the afternoon. Subsequently the snow quickly exited the area 5 – 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 22 – 26 degrees.

Quick hitting snow on December 15th. On the early afternoon of December 15th, steady snow quickly overspread the area between 12 – 2 PM, with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Soon after starting, the snow rapidly increased in intensity, with moderate to heavy snow impacting the area during the afternoon. Subsequently the snow quickly exited the area 5 – 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 22 – 26 degrees.

System brings snow/sleet December 24th into 25th. Light snow and sleet showers moved in on the evening of December 24th between 6 – 8 PM, however these showers quickly began to mix with rain, and became completely rain by 9 – 10 PM with temperatures that were 34 – 38 degrees. Then following overnight rain, another batch of mixed snow/sleet moved through between 4 – 6 AM. Finally, as the system exited flurries and scattered snow showers moved through on the morning of December 25th between 7:30 – 9 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 32 – 35 degrees. Winds following the event were quite strong, with gusts 40 – 50 mph.

System brings snow/sleet December 24th into 25th. Light snow and sleet showers moved in on the evening of December 24th between 6 – 8 PM, however these showers quickly began to mix with rain, and became completely rain by 9 – 10 PM with temperatures that were 34 – 38 degrees. Then following overnight rain, another batch of mixed snow/sleet moved through between 4 – 6 AM. Finally, as the system exited flurries and scattered snow showers moved through on the morning of December 25th between 7:30 – 9 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 32 – 35 degrees. Winds following the event were quite strong, with gusts 40 – 50 mph.

Clipper brings snow on December 30th . Snow overspread the area between 4 – 7 AM on the morning of December 30th with temperatures that were 16 – 20 degrees. Not long after starting, between 7 – 8 AM the snowfall rate became moderate to heavy. The moderate to heavy snowfall rates quickly tapered off to lighter snow by 8 – 9 AM. A brief burst of moderate snow returned 10 – 11 AM, before finally tapering to intermittent snow showers and flurries. Intermittent flurries and brief/light snow showers exited between 4 – 7 PM on December 30th with temperatures only rising to 26 – 30 degrees. Temperatures overnight on the 30th into the 31st dropped to 13 – 18 degrees.

Clipper brings snow on December 30th. Snow overspread the area between 4 – 7 AM on the morning of December 30th with temperatures that were 14 – 19 degrees. Not long after starting, between 7 – 8 AM the snowfall rate became moderate to heavy. The moderate to heavy snowfall rates during the morning tapered off to lighter snow by 11 AM – 1 PM, followed by flurries and light snow showers. Intermittent flurries and generally light snow showers exited between 4 – 7 PM on December 30th with temperatures only rising to 24 – 28 degrees. Temperatures overnight on the 30th into the 31st dropped into the mid-teens.

Potent Nor’easter brings wind and snow on January 4th. Light, intermittent snow overspread the area between 12 – 3 AM on January 4th with temperatures that were 26 – 29 degrees. The snow gradually increased in intensity to moderate rates by 5 – 8 AM, with periods during the late morning reaching 0.5 to 1.0” per hour. Moderate snow tapered back to lighter rates during the afternoon, before ending 4 – 6 PM aside from a few stray flurries, with temperatures that had fallen to 23 – 26 degrees. Wind gusts increased to 35 – 45 mph during the day producing significant blowing and drifting snow that lasted well after snow had ended. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Potent Nor’easter brings wind and snow on January 4th. Light, intermittent snow overspread the area between 12 – 3 AM on January 4th with temperatures that were 22 – 25 degrees. The snow gradually increased in intensity to moderate rates by 5 – 8 AM, with periods during the late morning reaching 0.5 to 1.0” per hour. Moderate snow tapered back to lighter rates during the afternoon, before ending 4 – 6 PM aside from a few stray flurries, with temperatures that had fallen to 18 – 22 degrees. Wind gusts increased to 35 – 45 mph during the day producing significant blowing and drifting snow that lasted well after snow had ended. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

A quick-moving system produced a wintry mix on January 8th. Light sleet and freezing rain moved in on the afternoon of January 8th between 1 – 3 PM with temperatures that were 29 – 31 degrees. Any sleet that mixed in initially quickly changed over to all freezing rain which continued through the evening before ending 8 – 10 PM. Temperatures that were steady during the event slightly cooled overnight to 26 - 30 degrees.

A quick-moving system produced a wintry mix on January 8th. Light sleet and freezing rain moved in on the afternoon of January 8th between 12 – 2 PM with temperatures that were 24 – 29 degrees. Any sleet that mixed in initially quickly changed over to all freezing rain which continued through the evening before ending 7 – 10 PM. Temperatures that were steady during the event slightly cooled overnight to 19 - 24 degrees.

Flurries and light snow showers on the morning of January 16th . With temperatures 27 - 31 degrees, intermittent flurries and light snow showers moved into the area between 3 – 6 AM on the early morning of January 16th. This activity came to an end by 8 – 10 AM the same day with temperatures that gradually rose into the low-40s by the afternoon. Any additional accumulations from the storm overnight into January 17th will be handled in a separate report.

Flurries and light snow showers on the morning of January 16th . With temperatures 24 - 28 degrees, intermittent flurries and light snow showers moved into the area between 3 – 6 AM on the early morning of January 16th. This activity came to an end by 8 – 10 AM the same day with temperatures that gradually rose into the mid-30s by the afternoon.
