Any additional accumulations from the storm overnight into January 17th will be handled in a separate report.

Storm brings rain, then snow on January 17. Intermittent rain showers changed over to snow on the early morning of January 17th between 2 - 4 AM with temperatures that were 32 - 36 degrees. The snow continued at light to moderate rates through the morning as temperatures dropped below freezing. Snow ended between 9 - 11 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 26 - 30 degrees and remained below freezing for the remainder of the day.

Storm brings rain, then snow on January 17. Rain began to mix with snow on the early morning of January 17th between 12 - 2 AM with temperatures that were 32 - 34 degrees. Any rain/snow mix changed over to all snow after 2 - 3 AM, continuing at light to moderate rates through the morning as temperatures dropped below freezing. Snow ended between 10 AM - 12 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 24 - 29 degrees and remained well below freezing for the remainder of the day.

Brush with a coastal storm and daytime disturbance January 30. Rain began to mix with snow on January 30th between 1 - 3 AM with temperatures that were 34 - 37 degrees. The rain-snow mix tapered off between 4 - 6 AM, before returning light to moderate snow arrived 7 - 10 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing. Snowfall was steadiest during the early afternoon, before coming to an end between 4 - 6 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 27 - 30 degrees. Due to warm antecedent conditions pavement accumulations were variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Brush with a coastal storm and daytime disturbance January 30. A few light snow showers moved in on January 30th between 1 - 3 AM with temperatures that were 33 - 36 degrees. This light activity tapered off between 4 - 6 AM, before a return of light to moderate snow between 7 - 9 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing. Snowfall was steadiest during the early afternoon, before coming to an end between 4 - 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 26 - 29 degrees. Due to warm antecedent conditions pavement accumulations were variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Cold front brings rain and snow February 1 - 2. Overnight February 1st into the 2nd between 3 - 6 AM temperatures dropped to 34 - 37 degrees as a few flakes mixed with the rain as the front exited. In the wake of the front, flurries and intermittent snow showers began to affect the area between 5 - 7 AM. This activity came to an end by 10 AM - 12 PM on February 2nd with temperatures that had further fallen to 25 - 28 degrees.

Cold front brings rain and snow February 1 - 2. Overnight February 1st into the 2nd between 3 - 6 AM temperatures dropped to 32 - 35 degrees as rain gave way to brief snow as the front exited. In the wake of the front, flurries and intermittent snow showers began to affect the area 7 - 8 AM before ending by 10 AM - 12 PM on February 2nd with temperatures that had further fallen to 22 - 26 degrees. Due to initially marginal temperatures, elevation played a significant role in accumulations.

Storm brings a wintry mix February 7th. Snow and sleet showers moved into the area on February 7th between 5 – 6 AM with temperatures that were 27 – 30 degrees. Any snow/sleet was short lived as the precipitation changed over to steady freezing rain between 6 – 8 AM. As the freezing rain progressed temperatures gradually warmed above freezing by 10 – 11 AM, bringing an end to additional ice accretion. Following the end of freezing rain, periods of moderate to heavy rain continued through the early evening with temperatures that climbed well into the 40s.

Storm brings a wintry mix February 7th. Snow and sleet showers moved into the area on February 7th between 5 – 7 AM with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Any snow/sleet was relatively short lived as the precipitation changed over to steady freezing rain between 7 – 10 AM. As the freezing rain progressed temperatures gradually warmed above freezing by 1 – 3 PM, bringing an end to additional ice accretion. Following the end of freezing rain, periods of moderate to heavy rain continued through the early evening with temperatures that climbed into the mid-upper 30s.

A period of moderate to heavy snow the evening of February 17th. Between 4-6 PM, a mix of rain and snow arrived, quickly turning to all snow. The snow fell at a moderate to heavy intensity for a portion of the evening before it tapered and ended between 10 PM and Midnight. As the snow ended, it mixed back with rain in spots. Temperatures throughout the event were 32-35 degrees.

A period of heavy snow the evening of February 17th. Between 4-6 PM, snow started across the area and it rapidly became moderate to heavy in intensity. Snow continued through evening until ending 9-11 PM. As and after the snow stopped, patchy drizzle and fog remained into a portion of the early overnight. Temperatures throughout the event were 31-33 degrees.

Powerful Nor’easter Brings Rain, Snow and Wind on March 2nd. Overnight rain subsequently changed over to snow, between 10 AM and 12 PM as the potent coastal storm developed on March 2nd with temperatures near 40 degrees. The snow fell steady to heavy at times during the early afternoon prior to tapering down to lighter snow and flurries by the evening, before completely ending between 10 PM and midnight. While wintry precipitation was falling, temperatures fell marginally to 33 - 36 degrees. The storm brought long duration, damaging wind gusts commonly 40 - 50 mph, with a few gusts over 60 mph.

Powerful Nor’easter Brings Rain, Snow and Wind on March 2nd. Overnight rain subsequently changed over to snow, between 9 - 11 AM as the potent coastal storm developed on March 2nd with temperatures in the upper 30s. The snow fell heavily during the afternoon, with snowfall rates around 1 inch per hour, producing extreme reductions in visibility. Snow tapered down to lighter snow and flurries by the evening, before completely ending between 10 PM to midnight. While wintry precipitation was falling, temperatures fell marginally to 32 - 36 degrees. The storm brought long duration, damaging wind gusts commonly 40 - 50 mph, with a few gusts over 60 mph, resulting in near blizzard conditions.

Nor’easter brings intense, wet snow March 6 - 7. Rain on the night of March 6th began to mix with and then quickly changed over to wet snow between 10 PM and midnight. The snow fell steadily at moderate rates during the early morning hours of March 7th. The wet snow tapered back to lighter rates during the morning, even mixing back with rain in spots, before changing back to all snow as rates dramatically increased between 11 AM and 1 PM. During the afternoon, the snowfall rates became very heavy, reaching 1-3” per hour, even producing lightning and thunder. This intense snow band tapered back to lighter snows by 4 - 5 PM, before completely ending by 5 - 6 PM. Temperatures that were 33 - 36 degrees for the duration of the event slightly fell to 32 - 34 degrees at night. Due to the wet, heavy snow, there were numerous downed trees and power outages. Also, banding of snow and small differences in elevation were important factors in the significant variability of snowfall totals.

Nor’easter brings intense, wet snow March 6 - 7. Rain on the night of March 6th began to mix with, and then quickly changed over to wet snow between 10 PM and midnight. The snow fell steadily at moderate rates during the early morning hours of March 7th. The wet snow waned somewhat during the late morning, before snowfall rates dramatically increased between 11 AM and 1 PM. During the early afternoon on the 7th the snowfall rates became very heavy, reaching 1-3” per hour, even producing lightning and thunder. This intense snow band tapered back to lighter snows by 3 - 4 PM, before completely ending by 4 - 5 PM. Temperatures that were 32 - 36 degrees for the duration of the event fell to 28 - 32 degrees at night. Due to the wet, heavy snow, there were numerous downed trees and power outages. Also, banding of snow and small differences in elevation were important factors in the significant variability of snowfall totals.

Brush with a coastal storm brings a mix of rain and snow on March 12 – 13. Intermittent rain showers on the evening of the 12th began to mix with wet snow starting 10 PM – midnight with temperatures that were 33 – 36 degrees. This light, but steady mix of rain and snow became all snow by 3 – 4 AM before ending between 8 – 10 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing.

Brush with a coastal storm brings snow on March 12 – 13. Flurries and intermittent snow showers (initially mixed with light rain) started to impact the area on the 12th between 5 – 8 PM with temperatures that were 33 – 36 degrees. The snow showers became steady during the late evening with temperatures that dropped to near 32 degrees. The period of snow continued at light to briefly moderate intensity during the early overnight before tapering back to lighter and more scattered activity by 1 – 4 AM. A few final flurries ended 5 – 8 AM on the 13th with temperatures that bottomed out just below 32 degrees.

Wintry mix on March 20 with some significant sleet accumulation. Snow moved into the region between 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM on March 20. th. .  Moderate snow at the onset quickly changed over to a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and patchy freezing rain through midday. There were some significant periods of sleet during the afternoon, which led to a dense accumulation on all surfaces. The wintry mix continued into the evening hours until the precipitation mostly moved out of the area between 8:30 – 10:30 PM. Any patchy drizzle that lingered was very brief and isolated. Temperatures started 33 – 36 degrees and then fell to 28 – 32 during the majority of the wintry precipitation. . This report covers precipitation that occurred through midnight March 21st, an additional period of precipitation occurred on March 21st that will be covered in a separate report.

Wintry mix on March 20 with some significant sleet accumulation. Snow moved into the region between 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM on March 20. th. .  Moderate snow at the onset quickly changed over to a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and patchy freezing rain through midday. There were some significant periods of sleet during the afternoon, which led to a dense accumulation on all surfaces. The wintry mix continued into the evening hours until the precipitation mostly moved out of the area between 8:30 – 10:30 PM. Any patchy drizzle that lingered was very brief and isolated. Temperatures started 33 – 36 degrees and then fell to 28 – 32 during the majority of the wintry precipitation. . This report covers precipitation that occurred through midnight March 21st, an additional period of precipitation occurred on March 21st that will be covered in a separate report.

Late-season coastal storm produced some heavy snow.  March 21. st. – 22. nd. A light mix of intermittent rain and sleet developed across the region between 12 – 3 AM the 21st.  Rain and sleet changed to a mix of snow and sleet before becoming all snow through mid-morning.   Snow continued through the day, falling at rates of up to 1 inch per hour.  The intensity of snow decreased shortly after sundown, with light snow tapering off to a few lingering flurries between 1 – 4 AM on the 22nd.  Temperatures started at 34 – 37 during precipitation onset, falling to 30 – 32 during snowfall (coldest during heavier snowfall).

Late-season coastal storm produced some heavy snow . March 21. st. – 22. nd. A light wintry mix of rain, snow, and sleet developed across the region between 12 – 2 AM on the 21st.  Mixed precipitation changed over to snow shortly after sunrise, becoming moderate to heavy at times.  Snow continued through the day, falling at rates of up to 1 – 2 inches per hour.  The intensity of snow decreased near sundown, with light snow tapering off to a few lingering flurries between 1 – 4 AM on the 22nd.  Temperatures started at 33 – 35 during precipitation onset, falling to 28 – 32 during snowfall.

A late season storm brings a mix of snow, sleet, and rain April 2. Rain on the early morning of April 2nd began to mix with sleet and snow by 4 - 7 AM with temperatures that were in the mid-upper 30s. The snow, sleet and rain mix became primarily snow and sleet around 9 AM with temperatures that remained above freezing. The event ended soon thereafter by 9 - 10 AM with temperatures that peaked in the mid 40s during the afternoon. Due to marginal temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

A late season storm brings a mix of snow, sleet, and rain April 2. Rain on the early morning of April 2nd began to mix with sleet and snow by 3 - 5 AM with temperatures that were in the mid 30s. The snow, sleet and rain mix became primarily snow and sleet around sunrise with temperatures that fell to near 32. The event ended soon thereafter, by 9 - 11 AM with temperatures that peaked in the low 40s during the afternoon. Due to marginal temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Rain To Snow, Then Periods Of Snow. Rain briefly changed to some sleet before changing to all snow between 5 - 10 AM on November 26th.  This was followed by a clipper system that arrived during the overnight hours.  Light snow developed 9 - 11 PM on November 26th.  Periods of snow fell through the night and into the morning of the November 27th before tapering off between 10 AM - Noon.  Additional snow showers and flurries continued through about mid afternoon.  Temperatures were 30 - 34 degrees early on the 26th before falling into the mid and upper 20s (some low 20s in elevations above 1000 feet) during the overnight hours of the 26th into the morning hours of the 27th.

A period of wet snow, then flurries. Rain changed to a period of wet snow and snow showers that fell between 11 AM - 4 PM on November 22nd.  Additonal scattered snow flurries fell during the overnight with little or no additonal accumulaion.  Temperatures were 32 - 35 when the rain changed to snow, then fell into the 20s by morning.

Flurries and scattered snow showers. Scattered snow showers fell across parts of northern Vermont between 4 - 11 AM on December 7th.  There were additional flurries into the early afternoon.  . This was followed by another round of scattered snow showers between 9 PM later on the 7th to 3 AM on December 8th.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 33 degrees with the daytime snow showers, but fell into the low to mid 20s with the second round of snow early on the 8th.
Coastal Storm Produces A Period Of Snow. A period of light snow fell across much of northwest Vermont between 6 PM, December 9th and Midnight, December 10th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 32 degrees.

On and off snow showers. An extended period of lake effect snow showers impacted much of northern Vermont.  Flurries and scattered snow showers (also isolated heavier snow squalls) fell across the area between 10 PM on December 10th and 8 AM December 11th.  Temperatures were mainly in the in the low and mid 20s.

Heavy Snow For Northern Vermont. A strengthening area of low pressure provided northern Vermont with a heavy snowfall.  Snow developed 1 – 4 AM on December 12th and continued through the morning and afternoon.  The snow fell heavy at times and was accompanied by wind gusts over 30 mph.  The snow tapered off during the evening hours, but continued to fall intermittently through the overnight and into the morning of the 13th.  (Additional snow showers and flurries returned later that morning and into the afternoon of December 13th, but that will be covered in a separate Certified Snowfall Report).  Temperatures throughout the snowstorm were in the low to mid teens.

On & Off Snow Showers. After the widespread snowfall came to an end early on December 13th, additional snow showers quickly developed across much of northern Vermont.  While it didn't snow continuously, snow showers and flurries fell on and off between 8 AM and 4 PM on the 13th.  The higher elevations saw a few heavier squalls and not as many breaks to the snow.  Additional flurries fell into the evening hours.  It was very windy as well, gusts over 30 mph were reported.  Temperatures were very cold ranging from the single digits and low teens (highest elevations) to to the low 20s.

Overnight Snow Showers. Flurries and scattered light snow showers fell across the area between 9 PM, December 15th and 3 AM, December 16th.  Temperatures ranged from the single digits (higher elevations) to the low and mid teens.

On & Off Snow Showers. Scattered flurries along with a few light snow showers fell across much of northern Vermont during the morning hours of December 16th.  However, a more widespread band of snow showers (along with a few heavier squalls) fell between 11 AM - 5 PM later on the 16th. A few more flurries continued through the evening before completely ending by Midnight of December 17th.  Temperatures were mainly in the teens, but a few locations in the higher elevations remained in the single digits.

More Snow For Vermont. After some early morning flurries, light snow developed across the area between 9 AM - Noon on December 18th.  The snow fell on and off into the evening (mixed with sleet at times) before tapering off between 10 PM - 1 AM December 19th.  Temperatures were in the teens when the snow began, then climbed into upper 20s to low 30s as the snow came to an end.

Scattered Snow Showers. As low pressure exited New England, colder air swept across the area. This changed any rain showers back to flurries and scattered snow showers during the early morning hours of December 20th.  The snow showers fell occasionally through the day and into the evening before ending completely by 9 PM later on the 20th.  Temperatures fell from the low and mid 30s into the 20s by 9 PM.

More Snow For Vermont. Snow developed across central and northern Vermont between 7 - 10 AM on December 22nd as low pressure and a warm front approached New England.  The snow fell heavy at times through the afternoon and into the evening before tapering off between 11 PM later on the 22nd and 2 AM on December 23rd.  Some additional light snow and snow showers moved through until about daybreak of the 23rd.  Temperatures were in the single digits and low teens when the snow began, then climbed into the low to mid 20s by the time the snow ended.

A Wintry Mix For Vermont. After overnight snow exited the area, precipitation returned between 5 - 8 AM on December 23rd in the form of sleet and freezing rain.  This wintry mix fell intermittently through the morning and into the afternoon (some locations changed to a period of rain) before ending 2 - 5 PM later on the 23rd.  Flurries and scattered light snow showers then developed during the evening hours before coming to an end by Midnight of December 24th.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s when the wintry mix began early on the 23rd, then climbed to 30 - 34 degrees during the afternoon, only to fall back into the low and mid 20s by Midnight of the 24th.

A White Christmas For Vermont. Periods of light to occasionally moderate snow fell across the area between 1 - 10 AM on December 25th as low pressure developed along the New England coast.  Flurries and scattered snow showers returned to region during the afternoon hours later on the 25th.  Temperatures ranged from the upper teens in the higher elevations to the low and mid 20s elsewhere.  Also, there was some blowing and drifting of the snow as the wind gusted over 30 mph, especially during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 25th.

Another Round Of Snow Showers. Intermittent flurries and scattered snow showers fell across parts of northern New Hampshire between 9 AM - 5 PM on December 26th.  Temperatures were mainly in the single digits (teens in some valley locations) through the day.

Some Light Snow And Flurries. A period of light snow and flurries fell across the area between 9 AM - 5 PM on December 29th.  There were some additional flurries along with a few light snow showers that blew through during the overnight hours from the 29th into December 30th.  It was very cold as temperatures ranged between -5 and 5 degrees.

Some Light Snow, Then Snow Showers. A period of light snow and flurries fell across much of northern Vermont between 1 - 6 PM on December 30th.  Scattered snow showers returned later in the evening before ending by Midnight of the 31st.  Temperatures were mainly in the single digits during the day, then fell to -10 to 0 after dark on the 30th.
A Few Light Snow Showers. Flurries and scattered light snow showers moved across parts of northern Vermont between 11 AM - 4 PM on December 31st.  Temperatures ranged -5 to 5 degrees.
Another Round Of Snow Showers. Flurries and scattered snow showers moved across parts of northern Vermont between 2 - 9 PM on January 2nd.  Temperatures were mainly in the single digits.

Periods Of Snow, Then Overnight Snow Showers. A nor'easter roared up the New England coast on January 4th, but the Burlington area was on the northwest fringe of the storm.  Light snow developed between 9 - 11 AM and fell through the afternoon before tapering off by evening.  This was followed by flurries and snow showers that fell overnight and into the morning of January 5th.  (. The snow showers continued on and off through much of the 5th, but that will be covered by a separate Certified Snowfall Total report beginning 7 AM, January 5th. ).  Also, winds gusted over 40 mph throughout the event.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s during the day of January 4th, then fell into the low to mid teens by the morning of the 5th. The gusty winds that accompanied this storm led to significant blowing and drifting snow.  This resulted in substantial variability of total snow accumulation.

Additional Snow For Vermont. As the nor'easter exited the area, occasional flurries and scattered snow showers fell throughout the day and into the nighttime hours of January 5th.  The snow showers continued all the way through the morning of January 6th before ending by the early afternoon.  . Note: the snowfall reflected in this Certified Snowfall Total report starts at 7 AM, January 5th.  . Wind gusts over 30 - 40 mph were common (especially on the 5th) lending to additional blowing and drifting snow and some variability to the accumulations.  Temperatures mainly ranged from -10 to 0 degrees.

Overnight Snow Showers. A fast moving disturbance produced flurries and a few light snow showers across the area between 9 PM, January 7th and 3 AM, January 8th.  There were additional areas of flurries that continued through 6 - 7 AM on the 8th.  Temperatures ranged 10 - 15 degrees except for some single digits in the higher elevations.

On & Off Snow Showers. Intermittent snow showers fell across much of northern Vermont from 7 AM, January 8th into the morning hours of January 9th.  The most organized periods of these snow showers were between 8 AM - 1 PM on January 8th, then again between 3 - 8 AM on January 9th.  Temperatures on the 8th were mainly in the low to mid 20s, before rising into the upper 20s to low 30s by the morning of the 9th.

Rain To Wintry Mix. Rain changed to a brief period of freezing rain between 9 - 11 PM on January 12th.  The freezing rain then changed to a period of sleet before changing to snow.  The snow fell into the morning of January 13th before tapering off to flurries between 10 AM - Noon.  Flurries continued at times through the afternoon.  Also, the wind gusted over 30 mph during the morning hours of the 13th.  Temperatures were in the low 30s during the changeover, then quickly fell through the 20s and into the low teens as the snow tapered off.

Periods Of Light Snow For Northern Vermont. A slow moving storm system trekked across southern New England between January 16 - 17th and produced periods of light snow across northern Vermont.  Flurries and snow showers first moved through the region 3 - 8 AM on January 16th.  After some late morning and afternoon flurries, another period of light snow fell from 7 PM of the 16th - Midnight of January 17th.  Areas of flurries returned for the daytime hours of the 17th with very little additional accumulation.  Another round of flurries and light snow showers fell into the morning hours of January 18th.  . Note: any snow that fell after 7 AM on January 18th will be covered in a separate Certified Snowfall Report.  . Temperatures started out in the single digits early on January 16th, then climbed into the low to mid 20s during the afternoon hours of the 17th.

Light Snow And Flurries. Periods of light snow continued to fall early on January 18th through the late morning hours as a disturbance finally exited the area.  Occasional flurries dotted the landscape for most of the afternoon, but scattered light snow showers returned between Midnight - 5 AM on January 19th.  Temperatures were in the low teens to start out the 18th, then held in the mid to upper teens for the overnight snow showers.

A Wintry Mix For Northern Vermont. A period of light snow fell across the area between 2 – 6 PM on January 22. nd. .  The snow then changed to sleet and freezing rain during the evening hours and continued through about Midnight of January 23. rd. .  A plain rain fell throughout much of the 23. rd. before ending as a few flurries during the overnight hours into January 24. th. .  Temperatures started off in the mid to upper 20s before climbing to 30 – 32 degrees during the period of sleet and freezing rain.

Periods Of Overnight Snow. After some flurries and scattered light snow showers during the daytime hours of February 1st, periods of snow fell between 9 PM later that evening and 3 AM on February 2nd.  Temperatures were in the low 30s when the periods of snow entered the area, but quickly fell into the mid and upper teens as the snow exited on the 2nd.

Periods Of Snow For Northern Vermont. Periods of snow developed over the area between 8 - 11 AM on February 4th.  The snow fell on and off through the afternoon and into the evening before ending 7 - 10 PM later on the 4th.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 32 degrees.  There was another period of snow between 4 - 7 AM on February 5th. Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s for this early morning snowfall.

A Snowy Wednesday For Vermont. Snow developed across the area between 9 - 11 AM on February 7th.  The snow continued heavy at times through the afternoon and into the evening before ending 7 - 9 PM later on the 7th.  A few flurries and light snow showers then fell into the early morning hours of February 8th.  Temperatures were mainly in the teens throughout the event.
Afternoon Wintry Mix. A period of light freezing rain (mixed with sleet at times) fell across the area between Noon - 4 PM on February 11th.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 32 degrees.

Periods Of Snow For Northern Vermont. Snow fell on and off between 7 PM, February 9th and 1 AM, February 10th.  Scattered flurries then continued overnight into the morning of the 10th.  Another period of snow fell between 3 - 11 PM later on February 10th.  Temperatures were steady in mid to upper 20s.

Overnight Light Snow. After some late evening flurries, light snow developed across the area between 9 - 11 PM on February 17th.  Periods of light snow continued overnight before tapering off 5 - 7 AM on February 18th.  Temperatures were in the upper 20s to low 30s throughout the event.

Afternoon And Evening Snow Showers. Flurries and snow showers moved across the area between 3 - 9 PM on February 16th.  Temperatures started out in the low 30s then fell into the mid and upper 20s as the snow showers exited.

Wintry Mix To End The Weekend. Light snow arrived across the area between 7 - 8 AM on February 25th. The snow quickly changed to sleet, then to a period of freezing rain before changing to plain rain by 11 AM - Noon.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 32 degrees when the snow began, but climbed into the mid 30s by Noon.

A Period Of Afternoon Snowfall. After a few morning snow showers, a period of snow fell across the Burlington area between Noon - 5 PM on March 2nd.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degees through the afternoon.

Periods Of Light Snow And Snow Showers. Light snow developed across the area between 9 AM and Noon on March 4th. Intermittent snow, along with a few snow showers, continued through the afternoon and into the night.  The snow exited the region between 1 - 4 AM on March 5th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 34 degrees.

Long Duration Snow Event. A period of snow fell across the Burlington area between 10 AM and 1 PM on March 7th.  After a few afternoon and evening flurries, a steady snow developed between 7 - 9 PM later on the 7th.  The snow fell through the night into the morning of March 8th.  Periods of snow then continued through the day and into the night before tapering off after Midnight of March 9th.  However, snow showers developed towards sunrise later on the 9th and continued into the morning.  Also, winds gusted to 30 mph at times.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 32 degrees throughout the event.  . Snow accumulations reflected in this report go through 7 AM of March 9th.  Any snow that fell after this time will be recorded in a separate Certified Snowfall report.

Nor'easter Continues Through Late Morning. Periods of snow associated with the Wednesday - Friday nor'easter continued from 7 AM, March 9th until around 10 AM.  Then, additional flurries along with a few snow showers fell between 5 - 9 PM later on the 9th.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 31 degrees.

A Few Rounds Of Snow Showers. Flurries and scattered snow showers moved across the area during the late afternoon hours on March 10th.  However, a more organized area of snow showers and even a few snow squalls fell between 9 PM, March 10th and 2 AM, March 11th.  Additional flurries continued into the late morning hours of March 11th before ending by Noon.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

Coastal Storm Produces Long Duration Snowfall. After some evening and early nighttime flurries, a steady snow developed across the area between 1 - 3 AM on March 13th.  The snow continued through the day and into the night, heavy at times as snowfall rates reached 1 - 2" per hour.  By the morning of March 14th, the snow became more intermittent and showery.  However, this continued through the afternoon and into the night before finally coming to an end 3 - 5 AM on March 15th.  Temperatures through the entire event ranged 29 - 32 degrees.
Overnight Flurries. Scattered flurries along with a brief snow shower streaked across the area between 1 - 4 AM on March 25th.  Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s.

More Snow In April. Periods of snow fell across the Burlington area between 2 - 7 PM on April 6th.  Temperatures ranged 33 - 35 degrees. . Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.
Evening Snow Showers . Areas of flurries and scattered snow showers moved across the area between 5 - 8 PM on April 8th.  Temperatures ranged 28 - 32 degrees.

Evening Snow Showers. Occasional flurries fell during the late morning and afternoon hours of April 10th.  This was followed by scattered snow showers that moved across the area between 5 - 8 PM later on the 10th.  Temperatures were in the mid to upper 30s during the afternoon, but fell to 32 - 35 degrees by evening.  . Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

More April Wintry Mix. A mix of light snow, sleet, and freezing rain developed across the area between 2 - 4 PM on April 14th.  The wintry mix fell intermittently through the night and into the next morning before tapering off between 11 AM - 1 PM on April 15th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 30 degrees.
Overnight Wintry Mix. A period of freezing rain, mixed with sleet, fell across the area between 10 PM, April 15th and 2 AM, April 16th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

Coastal storm brings first snowfall of the season December 9th. A developing coastal system brought the first snow of the season across the area, beginning on December 9. th. . Snow broke out across the region generally between 7-10AM on the 9. th. , initially as flurries with temperatures in the mid-30s. However, as snow became steadier and increased in intensity, temperatures dipped to 29-32 degrees. Periods of light to moderate snow continued throughout the day before tapering off and ending between 7-10 PM. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime. .

Fast-moving clipper brings brief snow/flurries December 13. th. . A quick-moving system brought a brief period of flurries or very light snow (or snow grains) to the region which fell between 7-11PM on December 13. th. . Temperatures were 27-31 degrees during any snow.

Coastal system brings snow to the region on December 15. th. . A quick-moving coastal system brought a period of light to occasionally moderate snow on December 15. th. . Snow fell between 12-6PM with temperatures between 25-30 degrees.

Clipper system brings a widespread snowfall on December 30 . A quick-moving clipper brought snow to the area on December 30. th. . Snow broke out across the region between 2-5AM, and continued through 10AM-1PM with temperatures between 17-22 degrees. The snow fell either as flurries or light snow during the morning. A few scattered flurries returned during the evening hours, mainly 4-9PM. Temperatures rose to 27-31 degrees during the returning flurries. Some additional coatings occurred during these returning flurries.

Powerful coastal storm brings snow and strong winds to the area on January 3-4. A coastal storm strengthened rapidly off the coast and brought snow to the region on January 3-4. Snow began to break out between 10PM on the 3. rd. and 1AM on the 4. th. . The snow mainly fell with light intensity though some more moderate bands developed close to the Chesapeake Bay. While it was steady at first, the snow became more intermittent going into the late morning and mid-day before it tapered off by 11AM-2PM. However, a few flurries lingered as late as 4-6PM. Temperatures throughout the storm were 22-27 degrees. Strong winds developed during the storm as well, and strengthened throughout the time snow was falling. Sustained speeds of 15-25 mph and gusts of up to 25-35 were seen during the snow. These strong winds continued after the storm. . The strong winds led to blowing and drifting snow, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher than normal drifts.

Wintry mix impacts the area on January 8. th. . A disturbance slid through the region on January 8. th. and provided a wintry mix of light slight, freezing rain, and freezing drizzle. The wintry mix developed as a mix of light freezing rain and sleet across the area between 12-3PM on the 8. th. with temperatures hovering between 29-32 degrees. The wintry mix eventually switched to just light freezing rain/drizzle by 3-4 PM and continued intermittently into the evening. A steadier wave of freezing rain/drizzle swept through during the evening hours, eventually tapering off and ending between 8-11 PM as temperatures rose to 32-37 degrees. Due to the prior stretch of cold weather, icing occurred even with air temperatures above freezing.

Very light snow falls overnight January 15. A quick, very light snow fell across a localized area during the nighttime hours of January 15. The snow fell between 8PM-12AM with temperatures between 28-31 degrees, resulting in some light accumulation mainly on colder surfaces.

Snow impacts the area on January 17. A slow-moving disturbance pushed a round of light to briefly moderate snow into the region during the morning hours of January 17. th. . Snow broke out gradually between 1-4am and fell intermittently before quickly developing into a bout of steadier snow. This burst lasted into part of the morning rush before tapering back to flurries and ending through 6-9am. Temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees as snow began falling, and dipped into the mid 20s after the snow ended.

Quick-moving cold front brings brief snow to the area January 30. A fast-moving system brought a few snow showers to the region on January 30. th. . Precipitation initially began as rain, but quickly mixed with and changed to snow between 4-9AM. Temperatures were marginal and were between 34-38 degrees. As a result, any accumulation was limited to colder/grassy surfaces. Strong winds picked up during the event as well, with sustained speeds of 10-25 mph and gusts up to 35 mph.

Wintry mix affects the area on February 4 . A passing disturbance brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain to the area on February 4. th. . Areas of light snow overspread the region and fell mainly between 8-10am before beginning to mix with sleet and freezing rain. Temperatures hovered between 30-33 degrees during this time.  Eventually, a transition to all freezing occurred by 12pm, and freezing rain continued to fall into the afternoon with temperatures staying right around 32 degrees. Temperatures eventually warmed slightly to 33-34 degrees, but a few elevated surfaces continued to see icing issues until rain exited the region between 6-9pm.

Winter storm brings ice impacts to the region February 7. th. . A strong disturbance moving through the area with cold temperatures near the surface resulted in some icing from freezing rain on February 7. th. across the mid-Atlantic. As temperatures hovered between 30-32 degrees, a few scattered freezing rain showers developed and fell between 4-8AM. Then a break in activity occurred through mid-day, but a steadier period of freezing rain redeveloped and fell between 12-2pm. After 3-4pm, temperatures warmed to 33-35 degrees, which ended the icing threat. All rain exited the region by 6-8pm.

Strong storm brings a wintry mix of snow and sleet on February 17 . A strong system passed through the region on February 17. th. . As the system arrived, precipitation was initially light and intermittent, which allowed for a mix of plain rain, sleet, and snow. However, as intensity increased and precipitation became steadier, a transition to all snow occurred. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon and early evening. However, snow mixed back with combinations of sleet and plain rain before it ended, with even some periods of heavy sleet occurring. All precipitation tapered off and ended between 6-9pm. Temperatures throughout the event were 34-37 degrees.

Rain mixes with and changes to snow on March 6-7. As a coastal storm began to develop near the area, a few rain showers moved into the region during the evening hours of March 6 with temperatures between 36-40 degrees. However, these rain showers quickly mixed with and changed to snow between 7-10pm (with some sleet initially mixing in as well but any mixing with sleet was brief). Temperatures fell to 32-34 degrees within the snow, and it fell with light to moderate intensity. Rain began to mix back in with the snow at times during the morning hours of the 7. th. , mainly after 2-5AM as temperatures rose back up to 34-38 degrees. Intermittent mixing with snow continued through 8-11AM before precipitation tapered off and ended.

Scattered flurries and snow showers move through on March 16th. A few areas of flurries and brief snow showers moved into the region during the morning hours of March 16th, mainly between 5-9AM. Temperatures during the snow were 33-36 degrees and any accumulation occurred largely on colder and grassy surfaces.

Initial period of wintry mix on March 20. th. . Morning rain on the 20. th. began to mix with sleet at times beginning 11AM – 1PM as temperatures settled to 31 – 34 degrees. This mix continued through the afternoon and evening, briefly mixing with snow at times too. After 9PM, this wintry mix tapered too mainly drizzle and pockets of freezing drizzle as temperatures held near 32 degrees. A brief lull in precipitation followed shortly after Midnight as drier air moved in. This report reflects any wintry precipitation through around Midnight. Another steadier period of snow developed during the early morning of the 21. st. , which will be covered in a separate report.

Steady snow returned on March 21. st. . After a brief lull overnight, a light wintry mix of freezing drizzle, light sleet and snow returned between 4 – 6AM on the 21. st. . After 6AM, this turned to all snow, and became moderate to heavy through the morning and midday with snowfall rates around 1” per hour. Snow lightened in the afternoon and ended 4 – 7PM. Just a few flurries returned around Midnight. Temperatures through the event were 32 – 35 degrees, resulting in a wet snowfall.

Coastal storm brings first snow of the season. A potent coastal system brought snow to the area on December 9th. While precipitation initially started off as some flurries or even sprinkles during the pre-dawn hours, it quickly became all snow which began developing across the area between 5-8 AM and continued falling into the afternoon & evening. The intensity of snowfall was mainly light to moderate but did become heavy at times, especially during the mid-to-late morning hours. Snow gradually tapered off and ended between 5-8 PM. Temperatures mainly held between 28-34 degrees as snow fell.

Brief snow showers December 13th. Between 6-9 PM a few scattered snow showers and flurries moved through the region. These snow showers were mainly light and produced some minor accumulations, mainly on colder, grassy surfaces. Temperatures were 33-37 degrees.

Storm system brings light snow December 15th. A quick-moving, rapidly developing storm brought light snow to the region, which began 10 AM - 12 PM on the 15th. Mainly light snow, flurries and even some occasional snow grains and pellets fell throughout much of the afternoon before tapering off and ending 3 - 5 PM. Temperatures were 27 - 31 degrees as snow fell.

Clipper system brings snow December 30th. Between 12-3 AM on the 30th, light snow began falling across northern Virginia with temperatures in the upper teens and low 20s. Periods of light to moderate snow continued through the overnight hours before tapering off 4-6 AM with a few flurries lingering through 7-8 AM. Shortly after noon, flurries and a few widely scattered snow showers returned as temps rose into the mid-upper 20s to near 32. Flurries continued off-and-on through the afternoon before coming to an end during the evening hours.

Western edge of coastal storm impacts region January 3-4th. As a strong nor'easter rapidly strengthened off the mid-Atlantic coast during the late evening on the 3rd, areas of snow began moving into the region between 10 PM and 1 AM though places closer to the VA/MD border started as late as 2-4 AM. Areas of steadier light to occasionally moderate snow continued into the early daylight hours before becoming more intermittent with variable intensity by mid-morning. Lingering snow gradually tapered off to flurries from west to east, ending between 11 AM and 2 PM. In addition to the light-to-moderate intensity of the snow, winds increased to 15-25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph during and after the storm. Temperatures were mainly in the low-mid 20s throughout the event. . The strong winds led to blowing and drifting snow, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Wintry mix of freezing rain and sleet January 8th. Beginning 11 AM to 2 PM on the 8th, a disturbance brought a mix of light freezing rain, drizzle and sleet to northern Virginia with temperatures 28-32 degrees. This light wintry mix continued at times before changing to mainly freezing rain/drizzle and becoming more intermittent and scattered in nature by mid-to-late afternoon as temperatures rose to 32-37 degrees. Intermittent freezing rain/drizzle began tapering off during the evening before ending for good 8-10 PM. Due to the prior stretch of cold weather, icing continued to occur despite temperatures rising above freezing.

Storm system brings light snow to NE Virginia.      A storm system moved in from the northwest, bringing snow to the area begining 12 - 3 AM Jan 17.  Intermittent light snow (<0.25"/hr) continued until between 7 AM -  10 AM.  Temperatures fell from the mid 30s into the mid 20s through the event.

Short period of snow early morning Jan 30. A cold front moved through the region early morning Jan 30, bringing snow to the region starting between 2 AM - 3:30 AM Jan 30. Snow was short lived, exiting the region between 3:30 AM and 4:30 AM Jan 30. Snow was generally light with a couple brief bursts of heavier snow. Temperatures were between 32 and 35 degrees during the event

Storm system brings wintry mix February 4th. Beginning 6-9 AM on the 4th, precipitation began moving into the area as snow with temperatures 30-34 degrees. By mid-to-late morning, the snow quickly changed to a mix of snow and sleet before becoming freezing rain, which persisted at times into the afternoon hours. As temperatures slowly rose above freezing, freezing rain transitioned to mainly plain rain, though pockets of freezing rain lingered in some areas. Despite temperatures rising just above freezing, a few spots continued to have icing, mainly on colder, elevated surfaces. Precipitation exited to the north and east during the evening hours, ending 6-8 PM.

Storm system brings brief freezing rain February 7th. Beginning 2-4 AM, scattered and intermittent precipitation began moving into the area. While a few sleet pellets fell at the onset, most of the precipitation fell as rain. In a few colder spots, temperatures were near 32 degrees which allowed for some brief and patchy icing, mainly on colder, elevated surfaces. Shortly after sunrise, temperatures rose above freezing everywhere, with only plain rain thereafter.

Storm system brings snow & sleet February 17th. Combinations of snow, rain & sleet began moving into the area between 1 - 3 PM with temperatures 37 - 42 degrees. As temperatures cooled to 32 - 34 degrees, mixed precipitation became predominantly snow which quickly became moderate at times during the mid-to-late afternoon hours. As intensity of precip began to lighten up late in the day, sleet and rain began mixing in again before finally changing to all rain and ending 7 - 9 PM.

Storm System Brings Wintry Mix of Rain, Snow & Sleet March 6-7. With temperatures initially in the low-mid 40s, areas of rain began pushing into the region between 6-8 PM on the 6th. Soon after rain began, temperatures then quickly cooled to 34-38 degrees which allowed for rain to mix with sleet and snow. Mixed precipitation then changed to a brief period of mainly light snow, producing some minor accumulations on colder, grassy surfaces. Towards or shortly after midnight, any remaining snow changed back over to rain before ending 12-2 AM.

Snow showers and flurries March 16th. Between 6 and 9 AM on the 16th, an area of snow showers and flurries moved across northern Virginia. Any particular snow shower that went through was brief and didn't last for more than 30 minutes. The intensity of snow was mostly light outside of some briefly moderate bursts with only minor and scattered accumulations on colder, grassy surfaces. Temperatures were 32-37 degrees during snow.

Steady snow returned on March 21. st. . After a brief lull overnight, a light wintry mix of freezing drizzle, light sleet and snow returned between 4 – 6AM on the 21. st. . After 6AM, this turned to all snow, and became moderate to heavy through the morning and midday with snowfall rates around 1” per hour at times. Snow lightened in the afternoon and ended 4 – 7PM. Just a few flurries returned around Midnight. Temperatures through the event were 32 – 35 degrees, resulting in a wet snowfall.

Initial period of wintry mix on March 20. th. . Morning rain on the 20. th. began to mix with sleet at times beginning 12 - 2PM as temperatures settled to 31 – 34 degrees. This mix continued through the afternoon and evening, briefly mixing with snow at times too. After 9PM, this wintry mix tapered too mainly drizzle and pockets of freezing drizzle as temperatures held near 32 degrees. A brief lull in precipitation followed shortly after Midnight as drier air moved in. This report reflects any wintry precipitation through around Midnight. Another steadier period of snow developed during the early morning of the 21. st. , which will be covered in a separate report.

Brief wintry mix changes to rain on February 4th. Between 10 AM and Noon, a period of mixed snow, sleet and rain moved into the area before quickly changing to all rain between 12-2 PM. Temperatures were 33 - 36 degrees. The rain ended 8-10 PM and the temperature fell to 32 degrees in some spots late in the night.

Disturbance brings snow showers March 25. On the morning of March 25th between 5 - 8 AM, scattered snow showers moved into the area with temperatures that were initially 28 - 32 degrees. The flurries and snow showers continued generally intermittently, aside from a few better, albeit brief bursts of snow.  The activity exited the area by 11 AM - 1 PM with temperatures that had risen above freezing, specifically 43 - 47 degrees.
